(1) To leave someone, especially someone you are responsible for.
Example: How could she abandon her own child? 
(2) To go away from a place, vehicle etc permanently, especially because the situation makes it impossible for you to stay.
Example: We had to abandon the car and walk the rest of the way. 
(3) To stop doing something because there are too many problems and it is impossible to continue.
Example: The game had to be abandoned due to bad weather. 
(4) To stop having a particular idea, belief, or attitude.
Example: They were accused of abandoning their socialist principles. 
(5) To feel an emotion so strongly that you let it control you completely.
Example: She abandoned herself to grief. 
(6) To leave a ship because it is sinking.
(7) If someone does something with abandon, they behave in a careless or uncontrolled way, without thinking or caring about what they are doing.
Example: They drank and smoked with reckless abandon. 
(8) To stop doing or using something because it is too difficult or unsuccessful.
Example: The company abandoned its takeover bid.
(9) If you abandon a ship or its cargo, you accept that it is too badly damaged to be saved, and so give it up to an insurance company in exchange for an insurance payment.
(10) To leave an organization because you believe that it is going to fail soon.
Example: The chairman and most of the board members had already abandoned ship.
(11) To no longer continue with a legal case etc.
Example: They decided to abandon their claim for damages.

(1) An abandoned building, car, boat etc has been left by the people who owned or used it.
Example: The car was found abandoned in bristol. 
(2) An abandoned person or animal has been left completely alone by the person that was looking after them.
(3) Behaving in a wild and uncontrolled way.
(1) To behave in a way that shows you accept that someone has complete power over you.

(1) To become less strong or decrease.

(2) To become less strong or damaging, or to make something do this.

(1) Used when you are comparing two people, things, situations etc.

Example: I saw peter as i was getting off the bus.

Example: As it was getting late, i turned around to start for home.

(15) Because of the situation that actually exists – used when that situation is different from what you expected or needed.

(16) Starting from a particular time or date and continuing.

Example: Profits this year are $2.5 million as against $4 million last year.  250  400 
(18) Concerning something.

(19) Used when describing someone or something in a way that is not quite exact.
Example: Jim radcliffe became our idol, as it were, the man we all wanted to be.   
(20) Used to add that what you have said is also true of someone or something else.
Example: Eves very tall, as was her mother. 
(21) In the way that people usually do something or how they normally behave – often used humorously by people after they have mentioned doing something strange or unusual.

(1) An act of violence that is intended to hurt a person or damage a place.
Example: There have been several attacks on foreigners recently. 
(2) The act of using weapons against an enemy in a war.
Example: The attack began at dawn. 
(3) A strong and direct criticism of someone or something.
Example: The magazine recently published a vicious personal attack on the novelist. 
(4) A sudden short period of suffering from an illness, especially an illness that you have often.
Example: I had a bad attack of flu at christmas. 
(5) A short period of time when you suddenly feel extremely frightened or worried and cannot think normally or deal with the situation.
Example: Her heart began to pound frantically, as if she were having a panic attack. 
(6) Actions that are intended to get rid of or stop something such as a system, a set of laws etc.
Example: The new measures were seen by many as an attack on the scottish way of life. 
(7) An attempt by a player or group of players to score goals or win points.
Example: Heath will play alongside smith in attack. 
(8) When something such as a disease, insect, or chemical damages something.
Example: Unfortunately, the carved ceilings have suffered woodworm attack over the years. 
(9) To deliberately use violence to hurt a person or damage a place.
Example: She was attacked while walking home late at night. 
(10) To start using guns, bombs etc against an enemy in a war.
Example: Army tanks attacked a village near the capital on sunday. 
(11) To criticize someone or something very strongly.
Example: Last year dr travis publicly attacked the idea that abortion should be available on demand. 
(12) If something such as a disease, insect, or chemical attacks something, it damages it.
Example: A cruel disease that attacks the brain and nervous system 
(13) To begin to do something in a determined and eager way.
Example: She immediately set about attacking the problem. 
(14) To move forward and try to score goals or win points.
Example: Brazil began to attack more in the second half of the match.

(1) If a building, wall etc collapses, it falls down suddenly, usually because it is weak or damaged.
Example: Uncle teds chair collapsed under his weight. 
(2) To suddenly fall down or become unconscious because you are ill or weak.
Example: He collapsed with a heart attack while he was dancing. 
(3) If a system, idea, or organization collapses, it suddenly fails or becomes too weak to continue.
Example: The luxury car market has collapsed. 
(4) If prices, levels etc collapse, they suddenly become much lower.
Example: There were fears that property prices would collapse. 
(5) To suddenly sit down, especially because you are very tired or want to relax.
Example: I was so exhausted when i got home, i just collapsed on the sofa. 
(6) If a piece of furniture or equipment collapses, or if you collapse it, you can fold it so that it becomes smaller.
Example: The legs on our card table collapse so we can store it in the closet. 
(7) If a lung or a blood vessel collapses, it suddenly becomes flat, so that it no longer has any air or blood in it.
(8) A sudden failure in the way something works, so that it cannot continue.
Example: The collapse of the soviet union 
(9) When something suddenly falls down.
Example: The collapse of an apartment building during the earthquake 
(10) When someone suddenly falls down or becomes unconscious because of an illness or injury.
Example: The president said he was fine after his collapse yesterday. 
(11) A sudden decrease in the value of something.
Example: The collapse of the stock market 
(12) If a company, organization, or system collapses, it suddenly fails or becomes too weak to continue.
Example: We did not want existing company pension schemes to collapse.
(13) When a company, organization, or system suddenly fails or becomes too weak to continue.
Example: The province has become sadly familiar with news of redundancies and company collapses.

(6) The form of an adjective or adverb that shows an increase in size, degree etc when something is considered in relation to something else. for example, ‘bigger’ is the comparative of ‘big’, and ‘more slowly’ is the comparative of ‘slowly’..

(1) The ability to do something well.

(1) To consist of particular parts, groups etc.

(1) An agreement that is achieved after everyone involved accepts less than what they wanted at first, or the act of making this agreement.

(1) The ability to think about something carefully or for a long time.

Example: The cheque has been credited to your account.

(18) The right-hand side of each account in double-entry bookkeeping, the side used for increases in liabilities (=the amount of debt that must be paid) or revenues.
Example: Every time an entry is made on the debit side, another entry of equal value must be made on the credit side somewhere in the books.
(19) If you are in credit, you have money in your bank account; be in the black.

(21) An arrangement with a bank for a loan, or bank lending in general.

Example: Bryant was unfairly dismissed from his post. 
(3) To tell someone that they are allowed to go, or are no longer needed.
Example: The class was dismissed early today. 
(4) If a judge dismisses a court case, he or she stops it from continuing.
Example: The case was dismissed owing to lack of evidence. 
(5) To end the innings of a player or team in the game of cricket.
(6) To remove someone from their job, usually because they have done something wrong.
Example: He was dismissed from his job at a bank for repeatedly turning up to work late.
(7) To state officially that a court case cannot continue because there is not enough evidence against the accused person.
Example: The prosecution offered no evidence and the case was dismissed.

(1) To refuse to do what someone with authority tells you to do, or refuse to obey a rule or law.
Example: You disobeyed my orders.

(1) A mental or physical illness which prevents part of your body from working properly.
Example: He suffers from a rare disorder of the liver. 
(2) A situation in which a lot of people behave in an uncontrolled, noisy, or violent way in public.
Example: A number of stadiums were closed because of crowd disorder. 
(3) A situation in which things or people are very untidy or disorganized.
Example: Everything was in disorder, but nothing seemed to be missing.

(1) To criticize someone or something in a way that shows you do not think they are very good or important.
Example: Matchams theatres were widely disparaged by architects.

(1) Consisting of things or people that are very different and not related to each other.
Example: A meeting covering many disparate subjects

(1) A difference between two or more things, especially an unfair one.
Example: A disparity between the rates of pay for men and women

(1) To send someone or something somewhere for a particular purpose.
Example: A reporter was dispatched to naples to cover the riot. 
(2) To deal with someone or to finish a job quickly and effectively.
Example: She dispatched (= beat ) her opponent 62,61.  6  2  6  1 
(3) To deliberately kill a person or animal.
(4) A message sent between military or government officials.
Example: A dispatch from headquarters 
(5) A report sent to a newspaper from one of its writers who is in another town or country.
(6) The act of sending people or things to a particular place.
Example: The dispatch of warships to the region 
(7) If you do something with dispatch, you do it well and quickly.
(8) To send something or someone to a place.
Example: Manufacturers dispatch vials of vaccine in large, insulated cartons.

(1) To make something go away, especially a belief, idea, or feeling.
Example: We want to dispel the myth that you cannot eat well in britain.

(1) To give something to people, especially in fixed amounts.
Example: Villagers dispensed tea to visitors. 
(2) To officially provide something for people.
(3) To officially prepare and give medicines to people.
(4) To not use or do something that people usually use or do, because it is not necessary.
Example: Ann suggested that they dispense with speeches altogether at the wedding. 
(5) If a machine dispenses something, it gives it to someone who puts in money, a special number etc.
Example: Four machines dispense a wide range of drinks and snacks.
(6) To sell or give medicines to people.
Example: A pharmacist will never dispense a prescription unless he or she is sure it is correct.

(1) A machine which provides a particular amount of a product or substance when you press a button or put money into it.

(1) The process of spreading things over a wide area or in different directions.

(1) If a group of people disperse or are dispersed, they go away in different directions.
Example: Police used tear gas to disperse the crowd. 
(2) If something disperses or is dispersed, it spreads in different directions over a wide area.
Example: The clouds dispersed as quickly as they had gathered.

(1) To take the place or position of something or someone.
Example: Coal has been displaced by natural gas as a major source of energy.

Example: Fifty thousand people have been displaced by the fighting.

Example: The water displaced by the landslides created a tidal wave.

(1) When a group of people or animals are forced to leave the place where they usually live.

(1) An arrangement of things for people to look at or buy.

Example: A fireworks display

(6) To show something to people, or put it in a place where people can see it easily.

(7) To clearly show a feeling, attitude, or quality by what you do or say.
Example: She displayed no emotion on the witness stand. 
(8) If a computer or something similar displays information, it shows it on its screen.
Example: I pressed return and an error message was displayed.     
(9) If a male bird or animal displays, it behaves in a particular way as a signal to other birds or animals, especially to attract a female.
(10) An attractive arrangement of objects for people to look at or buy, for example in a shop.
Example: Enormous shops with beautiful window displays
(11) Printing or page design to attract people’s attention, used especially in advertisements.

(12) The text or pictures you see on a computer screen, or the style, colour, brightness etc of this.

(13) To arrange objects in an attractive way for people to look at or buy, for example in a shop.
Example: The clothes were beautifully displayed.
(14) If a computer displays information, it shows it on its screen.
Example: If you try to open a document that is already open, the software will display an error message.

(1) Intended to be used once or for a short time and then thrown away.

Example: Disposable resources 
(3) Intended to be used once or for a short time and then thrown away.
Example: Disposable coffee cups
(4) Available to be used.
Example: Disposable resources

(1) When you get rid of something.

Example: Tanner had a lot of cash at his disposal .

Example: The profit or loss on the disposal of an asset must be accounted for.

(1) To like or approve of someone or something.

Example: A man disposed to depression

(1) A particular type of character which makes someone likely to behave or react in a certain way.

Example: A map showing the disposition of american forces

(1) Too much or too little in relation to something else.

(1) A serious argument or disagreement.

Example: It is beyond dispute that advances in medicine have enabled people to live longer.

Example: The facts of the case are still in dispute. 
(5) To say that something such as a fact or idea is not correct or true.
Example: The main facts of the book have never been disputed. 
(6) To argue or disagree with someone.

(7) To try to get control of something or win something.

(1) To stop someone from taking part in an activity because they have broken a rule.

(1) A situation in which something is prevented from continuing in its usual way.

(1) Not satisfied because something is not as good as you had expected.

(1) Someone who swims or works under water using special equipment to help them breathe.

(1) If similar things diverge, they develop in different ways and so are no longer similar.

(1) A change in the direction or use of something, or the act of changing it.

(2) Having the same rights, opportunities etc as everyone else, whatever your race, religion, or sex.
Example: Our constitution states that all men are equal. 
(3) To have the ability to deal with a problem, piece of work etc successfully.
Example: Im not sure hes equal to the task . 
(4) With neither side having any advantage over the other.
Example: This law will help small businesses to compete on equal terms with large multinational corporations. 
(5) If things are as you normally expect them to be.
Example: All things being equal, a small car will cost less than a larger one. 
(6) To be exactly the same in size, number, or amount as something else.
Example: Two plus two equals four. 
(7) To be as good as something else, or get to the same standard as someone or something else.
Example: Thompson equalled the world record. 
(8) Used to say that two things are as strong or as important as each other.
Example: Her distaste for books was equalled only by her dislike of people. 
(9) To produce a particular result or effect.
Example: A highly-trained workforce equals high productivity. 
(10) Someone who is as important, intelligent etc as you are, or who has the same rights and opportunities as you do.
Example: He treats all his staff as equals. 
(11) To be as good as someone or something else.
Example: The company proved to be the equal of its us rivals. 
(12) To be better than everyone or everything else of the same type.
Example: His paintings are without equal.

(1) A situation in which people have the same rights, advantages etc.

(2) When all people are treated in the same way and have the same opportunities.

(1) Calmness in the way that you react to things, which means that you do not become upset or annoyed.

(1) A statement in mathematics that shows that two amounts or totals are equal.

(1) A balance between different people, groups, or forces that compete with each other, so that none is stronger than the others and a situation is not likely to change suddenly.
Example: The government is anxious not to upset the economic equilibrium. 
(2) A state in which you are calm and not angry or upset.
Example: She struggled to recover her equilibrium. 
(3) The idea that there is a situation in an economy where supply and demand are naturally in balance. for example, the supply and demand of goods would be in balance through price changes, or the supply and demand of employment would be in balance through changes in wages.

(1) To provide a person or place with the things that are needed for a particular kind of activity or work.

(1) The act of giving someone something and receiving something else from them.
Example: An exchange of political prisoners 
(2) A short conversation, usually between two people who are angry with each other.
Example: A quiet exchange between the judge and the clerk 
(3) When people discuss or share ideas, information etc.
Example: The organization is dedicated to the free exchange of information. 
(4) The act of giving something you have bought back to the store where you bought it, for example because it does not work, fit etc, and taking something else instead.
Example: The stores policy is not to allow returns or exchanges. 
(5) A process in which you change money from one currency to another.
Example: Most capital cities have extensive exchange facilities. 
(6) An arrangement in which a student, teacher etc visits another school or university to work or study.
Example: Im here for one term, on an exchange with dr. fisher. 
(7) An arrangement in which you stay in someone’s home, do someone’s job etc for a short time while that person stays in your home, does your job etc.
Example: Kates in new york on an employee exchange so she can get some more training. 
(8) An event during a war or fight when two people, armies etc shoot or fire missiles at each other.
(9) A large building in a town that was used in the past for buying and selling corn, wool etc.
(10) To give someone something and receive the same kind of thing from them at the same time.
Example: We exchange gifts at christmas. 
(11) To replace one thing with another.
Example: He exchanged the black jacket for a blue one. 
(12) If two people exchange words, looks etc, they talk to each other, look at each other etc.
Example: Until this evening i had never so much as exchanged a word with him. 
(13) If two people exchange blows, they hit each other.
(14) To discuss something or share information, ideas etc.
Example: Its a place where people can chat and exchange ideas. 
(15) To complete the final stage of buying a house by signing a contract with the person you are buying it from.
(16) A market where goods, services, or shares are bought and sold, in return for money.
Example: The london international financial futures exchange
(17) A large building in a town, that was used in the past for buying and selling corn, wool etc.
Example: An historic old corn exchange
(18) The activity of buying and selling currencies.
Example: We have recently seen the removal of exchange controls (= limits on the amount of currency you are allowed to exchange ) .
(19) Money in the currency of a foreign country, for example money obtained through exports.
Example: When oil prices were depressed, mexico made a great effort to promote manufactured exports as an alternative source of foreign exchange .
(20) When you accept one thing in return for another.
Example: The exchange of goods and services
(21) An arrangement in which two people from different countries, areas etc do each other’s jobs for a period of time.
Example: He was on a six-month exchange at the factory where her father was works manager.
(22) To give someone something and receive something in return.
Example: The new system allows marketing data as well as orders and invoices to be exchanged.
(23) If a shop or company exchanges something you have bought, they take it back and give you a new one, for example because the thing you first bought has a fault.
Example: The store will not exchange goods without a receipt.
(24) If you exchange money, you get money in one currency for money in another.
Example: Where can i exchange my dollars for pounds?
(25) To complete the final stage of buying a house or other property by signing a contract with the person you are buying it from.
Example: The firm had just exchanged contracts on a nine-acre site.

(1) To make someone feel happy, interested, or eager.
Example: His playing is technically brilliant, but it doesnt excite me. 
(2) To cause a particular feeling or reaction.
Example: The court case has excited a lot of public interest. 
(3) To make someone feel sexual desire.
(4) To make an organ, nerve etc in your body react or increase its activity.
(5) To produce a lot of activity in a market, with a lot of people buying and selling stocks and shares.
Example: The auditors excited the market again yesterday by reporting sharply higher profits for the group.

(1) The feeling of being excited.
Example: The excitement of becoming a parent  [  ] 
(2) An exciting event or situation.
Example: We were both new to the excitements of life in the big city.

(1) Making you feel excited.
Example: An exciting discovery

(1) To say something suddenly and loudly because you are surprised, angry, or excited.
Example: no! she exclaimed in shock.

(1) To deliberately not include something.
Example: A special diet that excludes dairy products 
(2) To not allow someone to take part in something or not allow them to enter a place, especially in a way that seems wrong or unfair.
Example: A mainstream exhibition that excluded women artists 
(3) To officially make a child leave their school because of their bad behaviour.
(4) To decide that something is not a possibility.
Example: Social workers have excluded sexual abuse as a reason for the childs disappearance. 
(5) To deliberately not include something.
Example: The judge has decided to exclude her evidence.
(6) To not allow someone to take part in something or not allow them to enter a place.
Example: He plans to challenge the commissions decision to exclude him from the exchange.

(1) When someone is not allowed to take part in something or enter a place.
Example: The countrys exclusion from the united nations 
(2) When a child is officially made to leave their school because of their bad behaviour.
(3) To do something so much that you do not do, include, or have time for other things.
Example: Your essays tend to concentrate on one theme to the exclusion of everything else. 
(4) Something that is excluded from a contract.
Example: You will be sent full details of the exclusions of your insurance policy. 
(5) A particular event or risk that is mentioned in an insurance policy as something that the policy does not cover.
Example: Common exclusions in medical insurance policies are pregnancy, cosmetic surgery and treatment of aids.
(6) An amount that would normally form part of a person’s or company’s total income, but on which tax does not have to be paid.
Example: Customs are reviewing the current range of exclusions.

(1) Available or belonging only to particular people, and not shared.
Example: Our figure skating club has exclusive use of the rink on mondays. 
(2) Exclusive places, organizations, clothes etc are so expensive that not many people can afford to use or buy them.
Example: Bel air is an exclusive suburb of los angeles. 
(3) Deliberately not allowing someone to do something or be part of a group.
Example: A racially exclusive hiring policy 
(4) If two things are mutually exclusive, you cannot have or do both of them.
Example: Lesbianism and motherhood are not mutually exclusive. 
(5) Not including something.
Example: Our prices are exclusive of sales tax. 
(6) Concerned with only one thing.
Example: The committees exclusive focus will be to improve public transportation. 
(7) An important or exciting story that is printed in only one newspaper, because that newspaper was the first to find out about it.
Example: A new york post exclusive about the kennedy marriage 
(8) An exclusive agreement, contract, or right is one that a single person or organization has and no one else has.
Example: They have signed an exclusive agreement to market and sell the diamonds to retail jewelers in switzerland.
(9) Exclusive places, products etc are so expensive that not many people can afford to buy them.
Example: Bel air is an exclusive suburb of los angeles.
(10) If a figure is exclusive of a particular amount, it does not include that amount.
Example: The manufacturers operating costs fell 8%, exclusive of depreciation and amortization.

(1) Only.
Example: This offer is available exclusively to people who call now.
(1) The solid or liquid waste material that people and animals produce and get rid of from their bodies.
(1) To prove that someone is not guilty of something.

(1) A short journey arranged so that a group of people can visit a place, especially while they are on holiday.
Example: Included in the tour is an excursion to the grand canyon. 
(2) A short journey made for a particular purpose.
Example: A shopping excursion 
(3) An attempt to experience or learn about something that is new to you.
Example: The companys excursion into new markets

(1) Behaviour that is excusable can be forgiven.
Example: An excusable reaction of anger

(1) Used when you want to get someone’s attention politely, especially when you want to ask a question.
Example: Excuse me, can you tell me the way to the museum please? 
(2) To forgive someone for doing something that is not seriously wrong, such as being rude or careless.
Example: Ill excuse you this time, but dont be late again. 
(3) To allow someone not to do something that they are supposed to do.
Example: Can i be excused from swimming today? i have a cold. 
(4) To be or give a good reason for someone’s careless or offensive behaviour.
Example: Nothing can excuse that kind of rudeness. 
(5) To give someone permission to leave a place.
Example: May i please be excused from the table? 
(6) To say politely that you need to leave a place.
Example: Richard excused himself and went to his room. 
(7) Used to show that you are annoyed when someone has told you that you have done something wrong.
(8) A reason that you give to explain careless or offensive behaviour.
Example: Whats your excuse for being late this time? 
(9) A reason that you invent to explain an action and to hide your real intentions.
Example: I need an excuse to call her. 
(10) Used to say that someone’s behaviour is too bad to be explained or accepted.
Example: There is no excuse for such rudeness. 
(11) To explain why you are not able to do something.
Example: Please make my excuses at the meeting tomorrow. 
(12) Used when you think someone or something is very bad.
Example: Hes a rotten excuse for a lawyer. why on earth did you hire him? 
(13) A note written by your doctor or one of your parents saying that you were ill on a particular day.

(1) To kill someone, especially legally as a punishment.
Example: Thousands have been executed for political crimes. 
(2) To do something that has been carefully planned.
Example: The job involves drawing up and executing a plan of nursing care. 
(3) To perform a difficult action or movement.
Example: The skaters routine was perfectly executed. 
(4) If a computer executes a program or command (=instruction), it makes the program or command happen or work.
(5) To make sure that the instructions in a legal document are followed.
(6) To produce a painting, book, film etc.
Example: A boldly executed story 
(7) To do what is written in a contract, plan etc.
Example: The directors make the decisions but the managers have to execute them.
(8) When a computer executes a program or command (=instruction), it makes the program or command work.
Example: To make it easier, you can create a shell script to execute the program and invoke that.

(1) When someone is killed, especially as a legal punishment.

(1) A manager in an organization or company who helps make important decisions.

(1) Excellent and providing a good example for people to follow.

(1) Not affected by something, or not having to do it or pay it.

(1) The end of a period of time during which an official document can legally be used, or the end of a period of authority.

(1) The front part of your head, where your eyes, nose, and mouth are.

Example: Negotiators emerged grim-faced after the days talks.

Example: There are a few new faces in class this year.

(1) Something that you pass water, air etc through in order to remove unwanted substances and make it clean or suitable to use.

(1) To stay or move on the surface of a liquid without sinking.
Example: I wasnt sure if the raft would float. 
(2) If something floats, it moves slowly through the air or stays up in the air.
Example: I looked up at the clouds floating in the sky. 
(3) If sounds or smells float somewhere, people in another place can hear or smell them.
Example: The sound of her voice came floating down from an upstairs window. 
(4) To walk in a slow light graceful way.
Example: Rachel floated around the bedroom in a lace nightgown. 
(5) To suggest an idea or plan in order to see if people like it.
Example: We first floated the idea back in 1992.  1992 
(6) If the government of a country floats its money, the value of the money is allowed to change freely in relation to money from other countries.
Example: Russia decided to float the rouble on the foreign exchange market. 
(7) To sell shares in a company or business to the public for the first time.
Example: The company will be floated on the stock market next year. 
(8) To write a cheque when you do not have enough money in the bank to pay it.
(9) Used to say that someone can do or use whatever they like.
Example: You can add raisins, nuts, chocolate chips  whatever floats your boat.   
(10) To be present in a place.
Example: Theres a lot of cash floating around in the economy at the moment. 
(11) A large vehicle that is decorated to drive through the streets as part of a special event.
Example: We stood and watched the carnival floats drive past. 
(12) A sweet drink that has ice cream floating in it.
(13) A small light object that floats on the surface of the water, used by people trying to catch fish to show where their line is.
(14) A flat light object that you can rest part of your body on in water to help you learn to swim.
(15) A small amount of money that someone in a shop keeps so that they have enough money to give change to people.
(16) A time when shares in a company are made available for people to buy for the first time.
(17) A time when you sit in a flotation tank in order to treat illness or injury, or to relax.
(18) To sell new shares, bonds etc on a financial market.
Example: To finance the expansion, the airport has floated $30 billion in bonds, which should cover 75% of construction costs.
(19) To sell shares in a company on a stockmarket for the first time.
Example: The price of the companys shares on the day it floated on the stock market beat all expectations.
(20) If the government of a country floats its currency, or if the currency floats, its value is allowed to change in relation to other currencies after a period of time when it has been fixed.
Example: He had been responsible for sweeping economic reforms, including floating the australian dollar and deregulating the financial system.
(21) If a price, amount etc floats, it moves up or down slowly.
Example: The oil market let crude prices float lower.
(22) When shares, bonds etc are sold on a financial market, or when a company sells shares for the first time.
Example: The board is still talking with its investment bankers about the timing and terms of the float, which is expected to value the company at between $3 billion and $4 billion.
(23) When a currency is allowed to change in value in relation to others.
Example: Until the float of sterling in 1972 there were few restrictions on investment within the sterling area.
(24) The money made available to banks while customers’ cheques go through the banking system.
Example: Many consumers have long believed that bankers have lengthened the check-clearing process to use the float for their own benefit.
(25) The amount of notes and coins in the till of a shop, restaurant etc when they open for business.
Example: Cash floats should be rechecked to ensure that cashiers have enough change for the evening business.
(26) A small amount of money that is kept in an office for making small payments.
Example: A business credit card removes the need for a cash float.

(1) A group of sheep, goats, or birds.
Example: A flock of small birds 
(2) A large group of people.
Example: A flock of children 
(3) A priest’s flock is the group of people who regularly attend his or her church.
(4) Small pieces of wool or cotton that are used for filling cushions.
(5) A soft substance that is used to make patterns on the surface of wallpaper, curtains etc.
(6) If people flock to a place, they go there in large numbers because something interesting or exciting is happening there.
Example: People have been flocking to the exhibition.

(1) All the plants that grow in a particular place or country.
Example: Tourism is damaging the flora and fauna (= plants and animals ) of the island. 
(2) A british type of margarine made with sunflower oil, which is considered to be healthy because it is polyunsaturated.

(1) Made of flowers or decorated with flowers or pictures of flowers.
Example: A scarf with a bold floral pattern

(1) A florid face is red in colour.
Example: A middle-aged man with a florid complexion 
(2) Florid language, music, or art has a lot of extra unnecessary details or decorations.
Example: A book written in a very florid style

(1) To not know what to say or do because you feel confused or upset.
Example: I found myself floundering as i tried to answer her questions. 
(2) To have a lot of problems and be likely to fail completely.
Example: More and more firms are floundering because of the recession. 
(3) To be unable to move easily because you are in deep water or mud, or cannot see very well.
Example: They were floundering chest-deep in the freezing water. 
(4) A type of small fish that you can eat.

(1) To develop well and be successful.
Example: The economy is booming and small businesses are flourishing. 
(2) To grow well and be very healthy.
Example: Most plants will flourish in the rich deep soils here. 
(3) To wave something in your hand in order to make people notice it.
Example: She walked quickly to the desk, flourishing her cheque book. 
(4) With a large confident movement that makes people notice you.
Example: He opened his wallet with a flourish and took out a handful of notes. 
(5) A special or impressive part of something.
Example: Theres nothing like a luxurious dessert to give a menu a final flourish . 
(6) A loud part of a piece of music, played especially when an important person enters.
Example: A flourish of trumpets 
(7) A curved line that you use to decorate writing.
(8) If a business or industry flourishes, it is very successful and makes a profit.
Example: The economy is booming and many small businesses are flourishing.

(1) To deliberately disobey a law, rule etc, without trying to hide what you are doing.
Example: Some companies flout the rules and employ children as young as seven.

(1) If a price or amount fluctuates, it keeps changing and becoming higher and lower.
Example: Prices were volatile, fluctuating between $20 and $40.  20  40 
(2) If prices, income, rates etc fluctuate, they change, increasing or falling often or regularly.
Example: Dealers know that prices fluctuate and that capital losses can be expected.

(1) A change in a price, amount, level etc.
Example: The fluctuation in interest rates 
(2) The movement of prices, income, rates etc as they increase and fall.
Example: Fluctuations in profits resulted from differences between the volume of sales and the volume of production.

(1) Able to speak a language very well.
Example: She was fluent in english, french, and german. 
(2) Someone who speaks fluent french etc speaks it like a person from that country.
Example: He spoke in fluent italian. 
(3) Fluent speech or writing is smooth and confident, with no mistakes.
Example: He was a fluent and rapid prose writer. 
(4) Fluent movements are smooth and gentle, not sudden and sharp.
Example: She rose with the fluent movement of an athlete.

(1) Very light and soft to touch.
Example: A fluffy little kitten 
(2) Food that is fluffy is made soft and light by mixing it quickly so that a lot of air is mixed into it.
Example: Cream the butter and sugar until the mixture is light and fluffy. 
(3) Fluffy clouds look light and soft.
(4) Not serious or important.
Example: Her new book is a fluffy romantic fantasy.

(1) Fluorescent colours are very bright and easy to see, even in the dark.
Example: A fluorescent pink t-shirt  t 
(2) A fluorescent light contains a tube filled with gas, which shines with a bright light when electricity is passed through it.

(1) To become red in the face, for example when you are angry or embarrassed.
Example: Susan flushed deeply and looked away. 
(2) If you flush a toilet, or if it flushes, you make water go through it to clean it.
Example: Why do children never remember to flush the loo? 
(3) To force water through a pipe in order to clean it.
Example: They flush clean water through the pipes once a day. 
(4) To make someone leave a place where they are hiding.
Example: The government is determined to flush out the terrorists. 
(5) To make someone leave a place where they are hiding.
Example: The government is determined to flush out the terrorists. 
(6) To clean something by forcing water through it.
Example: The heating system needs to be flushed out once a year. 
(7) A red colour that appears on your face when you are angry or embarrassed.
Example: His words brought a warm flush to her face. 
(8) A sudden feeling of anger, embarrassment etc.
Example: She felt a sudden flush of anger. 
(9) The part of a toilet that cleans it with a sudden flow of water.
Example: The flush isnt working properly. 
(10) A set of cards that someone has in a card game that are all of the same suit.
(11) The beginning of a period of time when you are young etc.
Example: A group of adolescent boys in the first flush of manhood 
(12) A large number of things that happen or arrive at the same time.
Example: The spring brings a flush of young animals to the farm. 
(13) If two surfaces are flush, they are at exactly the same level, so that the place where they meet is flat.
Example: Make sure that the cupboard is flush with the wall. 
(14) If someone is flush, they have plenty of money to spend.
Example: Im feeling flush at the moment. 
(15) To have a lot of money at a particular time.
Example: Singapores savings rate is so high that the banks are flush with funds.
(16) To be very successful, and keen to achieve more success.
Example: Flushed by success in selling homes in the slump, developers now plan to do the same in the commercial property sector.
(17) A complete failure.
Example: You can get a dealer who is a busted flush at 30.

(1) If a bird or insect flutters, or if it flutters its wings, it flies by moving its wings lightly up and down.
Example: A small bird fluttered past the window. 
(2) To make small gentle movements in the air.
Example: Dead leaves fluttered slowly to the ground. 
(3) If your heart or your stomach flutters, you feel very excited or nervous.
(4) If your eyelids flutter, they move slightly when you are asleep.
Example: Her eyelids fluttered but did not open. 
(5) If a woman flutters her eyelashes at a man, she looks at him and moves her eyes to make herself attractive to him.
(6) A feeling of being nervous, confused, or excited.
Example: She was all in a flutter. 
(7) A sudden feeling that is not very strong.
Example: She felt a flutter of curiosity. 
(8) A light gentle movement.
Example: A flutter of wings 
(9) To risk a small amount of money on the result of something such as a horse race.
(10) To risk a small amount of money on the result of a horse race, football game etc.
Example: Lots of people like to have a flutter on the lottery.

(1) A situation in which things are changing a lot and you cannot be sure what will happen.
Example: Everything is in flux at the moment.

(1) A type of soft rubber with a lot of air in it, used in furniture.
Example: A foam mattress 
(2) A mass of very small bubbles on the surface of a liquid.
Example: The sea was covered in foam. 
(3) A substance which is like a very thick soft liquid with a lot of bubbles in it.
Example: Firefighters using water and foam are still tackling the blaze. 
(4) To produce foam.
Example: The green water splashed and foamed over the rocks. 
(5) To have bubbles coming out of your mouth because you are very ill.

(1) To give special attention to one particular person or thing, or to make people do this.
Example: He needs to focus more on his career. 
(2) To point a camera or telescope at something, and change the controls slightly so that you can see that thing clearly.
Example: She turned the camera and focussed on martins face. 
(3) If your eyes focus, or if you focus your eyes, you look at something and can see it clearly.
Example: All eyes focussed on her. 
(4) If you focus beams of light, you aim them onto a particular place.
(5) The thing, person, situation etc that people pay special attention to.
Example: The focus of recent research has been on environmental issues. 
(6) If your focus is on something, that is the thing you are giving most attention to.
Example: Our main focus is on helping people get back into work. 
(7) If something comes into focus, or you bring it into focus, people start to talk about it and pay attention to it.
Example: These issues have recently come into sharp focus (= people have started to talk about them a lot ) . 
(8) If a photograph or an instrument such as a camera is in focus, you can see the picture clearly. if it is out of focus, you cannot see the picture clearly..
(9) The clearness of the picture seen through an instrument such as a camera.
Example: He raised his binoculars and adjusted the focus. 
(10) When a company tries to serve particular groups of customers in a market with particular needs, rather than trying to serve the whole market.

(1) An enemy.
Example: Britains friends and foes 
(2) An international organization that tries to influence people and governments to protect the environment.
(1) A baby or young animal before it is born.

(1) Cloudy air near the ground which is difficult to see through.
Example: We got lost in the thick fog. 
(2) A state in which you feel confused and cannot think clearly.
Example: My mind was in a fog . 
(3) If something made of glass fogs or becomes fogged, it becomes covered in small drops of water that make it difficult to see through.
Example: The windscreen had fogged up. 
(4) To make something less clear.

(1) If the weather is foggy, there is fog.
Example: A foggy day in november 11 
(2) To not know at all.
Example: None of us had the foggiest idea about how to put the tent up. 
(3) If your mind is foggy, you cannot think or remember things clearly.

(1) A loud horn on a ship, used in fog to warn other ships of its position.
(2) A very loud unpleasant voice.

(1) Metal sheets that are as thin as paper, used for wrapping food.
Example: Cover the chicken with silver foil and bake. 
(2) Paper that is covered with very thin sheets of metal.
Example: Chocolates in foil wrappers 
(3) To emphasize the good qualities of another person or thing, by being very different from them.
Example: The simple stone floor is the perfect foil for the brightly coloured furnishings. 
(4) A light narrow sword used in fencing.
(5) To prevent something bad that someone is planning to do.
Example: A massive arms-smuggling plan has been foiled by the cia.

(1) To bend a piece of paper, cloth etc by laying or pressing one part over another.
Example: Fold the paper along the dotted line. 
(2) To fold something several times so that it makes a small neat shape.
Example: I wish you kids would fold up your clothes! 
(3) If something such as a piece of furniture folds, or you fold it, you make it smaller or move it to a different position by bending it.
Example: The chairs fold flat for storage. 
(4) To bend your arms so that they rest together against your body.
Example: George stood silently with his arms folded. 
(5) If an organization folds, it closes because it does not have enough money to continue.
(6) To cover something, especially by wrapping it in material or putting your hand over it.
Example: A silver dagger folded in a piece of white cloth 
(7) To hold someone closely by putting your arms around them.
(8) To gently mix another substance into a mixture when you are preparing food.
Example: Next, fold in the sugar. 
(9) A line made in paper or material when you fold one part of it over another.
Example: Bend back the card and cut along the fold. 
(10) The folds in material, skin etc are the loose parts that hang over other parts of it.
Example: Her dress hung in soft folds . 
(11) The group of people that you belong to and share the same beliefs and ideas as.
Example: The church will welcome him back into the fold. 
(12) A small area of a field surrounded by a wall or fence where sheep are kept for safety.
(13) A bend in layers of rock, caused by underground movements in the earth.
(14) Of a particular number of kinds.
Example: The governments role in health care is twofold: first, to provide the resources and, second, to make them work better for patients.  : 
(15) A particular number of times.
Example: The value of the house has increased fourfold (= it is now worth four times as much as before ) . 
(16) If a business folds or folds up, it stops operating or trading because it does not have enough money to continue.
Example: The u.k. engineering firm has folded today with the loss of 30 jobs.
(17) A particular number of times.
Example: The value of the house has increased fourfold in the last ten years (= it is now worth four times as much as it was ten years ago ) .
(1) A folding bicycle, bed, chair etc has parts that you can bend or fold together to make it easier to carry or store.

(1) The leaves of a plant.
Example: Dark green foliage
(1) The traditional stories, customs etc of a particular area or country.

(1) To do the same as someone else has done.
Example: Budget companies have been so successful that other airlines have had to follow suit and lower their fares.

(1) A very stupid thing to do, especially one that is likely to have serious results.
Example: Somerville bitterly regretted his folly at becoming involved. 
(2) An unusual building that was built in the past as a decoration, not to be used or lived in.

(1) To cause trouble and make people start fighting each other or opposing the government.
Example: They were accused of fomenting rebellion.

(1) A foolish action, remark etc is stupid and shows that someone is not thinking sensibly.
Example: Ive never heard anything so foolish in all my life. 
(2) A foolish person behaves in a silly way or looks silly.
Example: I was young and foolish at the time.

(1) A note at the bottom of the page in a book, which gives more information about something.
(2) A piece of additional information that is not very important but is interesting or helps you understand something.
Example: There was an interesting footnote to the story.
(1) A narrow path for people to walk along, especially in the country.

(1) Used to say who is intended to get or use something, or where something is intended to be used.
Example: Ive got a present for you. 
(2) In order to help someone or something.
Example: I looked after the kids for them. 
(3) Used to say what the purpose of an object, action etc is.
Example: A knife for cutting bread 
(4) In order to have, do, get, or obtain something.
Example: Are you waiting for the bus? 
(5) Used to say how long an action or situation continues for.
Example: Bake the cake for 40 minutes.  40 
(6) Used to talk about distance.
Example: We walked for miles. 
(7) If something is arranged for a particular time, it is planned that it should happen then.
Example: Ive invited them for 9 o'clock.  9 
(8) Used to say where a person, vehicle etc is going.
Example: I set off for work. 
(9) Used to say what the price or value of something is.
Example: A cheque for a hundred pounds  100 
(10) Because of or as a result of something.
Example: If, for any reason, you cannot attend, please inform us. 
(11) Used to say which thing or person your statement or question is related to.
Example: Im sure shes the ideal person for the job. 
(12) Used to say which person or thing your feelings are directed towards.
Example: I came away feeling sorry for poor old george. 
(13) Used to say at which meal you eat something.
Example: We had pasta for lunch. 
(14) Used to say which company, team etc you belong to.
Example: Ive worked for the bbc ever since i left university. 
(15) Supporting or in agreement with something or someone.
Example: We have studied the arguments for and against nuclear energy. 
(16) Used to say what a word or sign means.
Example: Whats the french word for happy?     
(17) Used to say that a particular quality of someone or something is surprising when you consider what they are.
Example: She looks young for her age. 
(18) As a representative of other people.
Example: Paisley claims to speak for the majority of local people. 
(19) Used to say what is possible, difficult, necessary, unusual etc.
Example: Its unusual for donald to be so bad-tempered. 
(20) Used to say that there is a relationship between one amount and another.
Example: For each mistake, youll lose half a point. 
(21) Used to say that something is not the kind of thing that someone likes or will enjoy.
Example: City life is not for me. 
(22) Used to say whether it is someone’s right or duty to do something.
Example: Its not for me to tell you what to do. 
(23) Used to say who or what prevents or prevented something from happening.
Example: If it hadnt been for you, i should have drowned. 
(24) Used to say that a particular kind of behaviour or situation is typical of someone or something, especially when you do not expect anything better from that person or thing.
Example: I know its outrageous, but thats melissa for you. 
(25) To be likely to be blamed or punished.
Example: Youll be in for it if she finds out what youve done! 
(26) Used to introduce the reason for something.
Example: I cannot tell whether she is old or young, for i have never seen her. 
(27) Abbreviation for free on rail.

(1) To go around searching for food or other supplies.
Example: People are being forced to forage for food and fuel. 
(2) To search for something with your hands in a bag, drawer etc.
Example: She foraged around in her purse and produced her ticket. 
(3) Food supplies for horses and cattle.
(4) An act of searching for something.

(1) A short attempt at doing a particular job or activity, especially one that is very different from what you usually do.
Example: It will be my first foray into local government. 
(2) A short sudden attack by a group of soldiers, especially in order to get food or supplies.
Example: Their nightly forays into enemy territory 
(3) A short journey somewhere in order to get something or do something.
Example: We make regular forays to france to buy wine.
(1) The quality of being patient, able to control your emotions, and willing to forgive someone who has upset you.

(1) To tell someone that they are not allowed to do something, or that something is not allowed.
Example: He was forbidden to leave the house, as a punishment. 
(2) Used to emphasize that you hope that something will not happen.
Example: supposing i had an accident. god forbid!     
(3) To make it impossible for someone to do something.
Example: Lack of space forbids listing the names of all those who contributed.

(1) Having a frightening or unfriendly appearance.
Example: We sailed past the islands rather dark and forbidding cliffs.

(1) A group of people who have been trained to do military work for a government or other organization.
Example: The riots were suppressed by government forces. 
(2) Military action used as a way of achieving your aims.
Example: Peace cannot be imposed by force . 
(3) Violent physical action used to get what you want.
Example: The police used force to overpower the demonstrators. 
(4) The amount of physical power with which something moves or hits another thing.
Example: The force of the explosion blew out all the windows. 
(5) A natural power or event.
Example: The force of gravity 
(6) A group of people who have been trained and organized to do a particular job.
Example: The companys sales force 
(7) Something or someone who is powerful and has a lot of influence on the way things happen.
Example: Betty coward was the driving force behind the project.   
(8) The powerful effect that something has on you.
Example: Even after 30 years, the play has lost none of its force.  30 
(9) To work together so that you can deal with a problem, be more powerful etc.
Example: Local schools have joined forces with each other to share facilities. 
(10) If a law, rule etc is in force, it already exists.
Example: The trade embargo has been in force for a year. 
(11) If a new law, rule, change etc comes or is brought into force, it starts to exist.
Example: Parking restrictions in the town centre came into force last month. 
(12) Because you have always done a particular thing and it is difficult to change.
Example: I get up at 6 o'clock every day out of force of habit.  6 
(13) If something happens by force of circumstance, events outside your control make it happen.
(14) A unit for measuring the strength of the wind.
(15) A word meaning the police force, used especially by police officers.
(16) People or things that increase the amount of good or bad in the world.
Example: The battle against the forces of evil 
(17) To make someone do something they do not want to do.
Example: Government troops have forced the rebels to surrender. 
(18) To make someone or something move in a particular direction or into a different position, especially through or using great strength.
Example: 5 westerly gales forced the ship off course. 
(19) To push very hard in order to get somewhere.
Example: The doctor forced his way through the crowd. 
(20) To make something happen or change, especially more quickly than planned or expected.
Example: The unfortunate events that forced his resignation 
(21) To open a door etc using physical strength, often causing damage.
Example: I forced the lock on the cupboard to see what was inside. 
(22) To do something that makes it necessary for someone to make decisions or take action, instead of waiting to see what happens.
Example: Polly decided to force the issue by demanding an explanation. 
(23) To make someone do something unwillingly or earlier than they had intended.
Example: Theyre reluctant to sell the house yet but the right offer could force their hand. 
(24) To make yourself smile, laugh etc even though you feel upset or annoyed.
(25) To stop yourself from showing that you are upset or frightened, especially with difficulty.
Example: Janet forced back her tears . 
(26) To make yourself eat or drink something, although you do not want it.
Example: I forced down a piece of stale bread. 
(27) To make yourself eat or drink something, although you do not want it.
Example: I forced down a piece of stale bread. 
(28) To make a plane land by threatening to attack it.
Example: The hijacked plane was forced down by military jets. 
(29) To make someone do or accept something even though they do not want to.
Example: Its no good trying to force a diet on someone. 
(30) To make someone tell you something by asking them many times, threatening them etc.
Example: I wasnt going to tell matt but he forced it out of me. 
(31) A group of people who have been trained and organized for a particular purpose.
Example: Our division has expanded its sales force (= the people in a company who sell the companys products ) to 160.
(32) If a law or rule is in force, it exists and must be obeyed.
Example: These regulations have been in force since 1997.
(33) Something or someone that has a strong influence on an activity or the way events develop.
Example: She is the driving force (= person or thing that has the strongest influence on the way things happen ) behind the groups creation.
(34) The way that the behaviour of buyers and sellers affects the levels of supply and demand in a particular market, especially when the government does nothing to change this.
Example: By ending the electricity monopoly, market forces rather than state utilities will set prices.
(35) Influence or authority.
Example: The citys code of practice does not have the force of law . (= the same authority as the law )
(36) If a situation forces you to do something, it makes you do it, even though you do not want to.
Example: Massive debts have forced them to close the store.
(37) To make something happen against the wishes of the people who are affected.
Example: The imposition of vat would force the closure of 20% of regional newspapers.

(1) A place where a river is not deep, so that you can walk or drive across it.
(2) One of the world's largest car companies, which is based in the us and has factories in many countries.
(3) A car made by this company.
(1) Someone who was a member of your family a long time in the past.

(1) A description of what is likely to happen in the future, based on the information that you have now.
Example: The weather forecast is good for tomorrow.

Example: Rain was forecast for the weekend. 
(3) A description of what is likely to happen in the future, based on information that is available now.
Example: The figures for 2001 are forecasts, the others are actuals.
(4) To make a statement saying what is likely to happen in the future, based on information that is available now.
Example: Turnover is forecast to grow 6.7% this year.

(1) The people, especially men, who were part of your family a long time ago in the past.
Example: What would our forefathers have thought? 
(2) Someone in the past who did something important that influences your life today.
Example: Two hundred years ago our forefathers established this nation.

(1) To be in a leading position in an important activity that is trying to achieve something or develop new ideas.
Example: The company has always been at the forefront of science and technology. 
(2) To be what someone is thinking about most, because it is very important to them.
Example: Fear of unemployment was at the forefront of everyones minds.

(1) The best or most important.
Example: One of the countrys foremost authorities on chemical warfare 
(2) In a leading position among a group of people or things.
Example: Sharpton was foremost among the protesters.

(1) Someone or something that existed before something similar that developed or came later.

(1) To think or know that something is going to happen in the future.
Example: Ive put your name on the list and i dont foresee any problems.

(1) For as long as it is possible to know what is likely to happen.
Example: The situation is likely to continue for the foreseeable future. 
(2) Fairly soon.
Example: There is a possibility of water shortages in the foreseeable future. 
(3) Foreseeable difficulties, events etc should be planned for because they are very likely to happen in the future.
Example: The judge found that it was not foreseeable that the fuel would catch fire.

(1) To show or say that something will happen in the future.
Example: The revolution foreshadowed an entirely new social order.

Example: The report illuminated the difficult issues at the heart of science policy.

(1) Lighting provided by a lamp, light etc.
Example: White candles, the only illumination, burned on the table. 
(2) A picture or pattern painted on a page of a book, especially in the past.
Example: The illuminations in a medieval manuscript 
(3) A show of coloured lights used to make a town bright and colourful.
Example: The blackpool illuminations 
(4) A clear explanation or understanding of a particular subject.

(1) An idea or opinion that is wrong, especially about yourself.
Example: They suffer from the illusion that they cannot solve their problems. 
(2) Something that seems to be different from the way it really is.
Example: He was unlikely to be satisfied with the illusion of power.

(1) To make the meaning of something clearer by giving examples.
Example: Let me give an example to illustrate the point .

Example: This dispute illustrates that the regime is deeply divided. 
(3) To put pictures in a book, article etc.
Example: Over a hundred diagrams, tables and pictures illustrate the book.

(1) A picture in a book, article etc, especially one that helps you to understand it.
Example: The book contains 62 pages of illustrations.  62 
(2) A story, event, action etc that shows the truth or existence of something very clearly.
Example: A striking illustration of 19th-century attitudes to women 19 
(3) The act or process of illustrating something.

(1) The opinion people have of a person, organization, product etc, or the way a person, organization etc seems to be to the public.
Example: Attempts to improve the image of the police 
(2) A picture that you have in your mind, especially about what someone or something is like or the way they look.
Example: He had no visual image of her, only her name. 
(3) A picture of an object in a mirror or in the lens of a camera.
Example: She peered closely at her image in the mirror. 
(4) A word, phrase, or picture that describes an idea in a poem, book, film etc.
Example: He paints a very romantic image of working-class communities. 
(5) To look exactly like someone or something else.
Example: Hes the spitting image of his mother. 
(6) In the same form or shape as someone or something else.
Example: According to the bible, man was made in the image of god. 
(7) The general opinion that most people have of a person, organization, product etc.
Example: Law suits hurt a companys image and may hinder future fund raising.
(8) A picture on the screen of a computer or television.
Example: A small company is leading the way in using lasers to create three-dimensional models from computer images.

(1) The use of words or pictures to describe ideas or actions in poems, books, films etc.
Example: The imagery of love

(1) Not real, but produced from pictures or ideas in your mind.
Example: As she listened, she played an imaginary piano on her knees.

(1) The ability to form pictures or ideas in your mind.
Example: A storyteller with an incredible imagination 
(2) To be something that someone imagines, not something that really exists or happens.
Example: Did you hear that noise, or was it my imagination?  
(3) Only existing or happening in someone’s mind, not in real life.
Example: For the refugees, home exists only in their imagination. 
(4) To make people feel very interested and excited.
Example: American football really captured the imagination of the british public. 
(5) To deliberately not describe something because you think someone can guess or imagine it.
Example: Mercifully, the writer leaves most of the physical horrors to our imagination. 
(6) If someone’s clothes leave little or nothing to the imagination, the clothes are very thin or are worn in a way that shows the person’s body.
Example: Her black satin dress left nothing to the imagination. 
(7) Used to tell someone that they can easily guess the answer to a question, so you should not need to tell them.

(1) Containing new and interesting ideas.
Example: An imaginative use of computer technology 
(2) Good at thinking of new and interesting ideas.
Example: An imaginative child

(1) To form a picture or idea in your mind about what something could be like.
Example: Imagine that you have just won a million pounds. 
(2) To have a false or wrong idea about something.
Example: Perhaps shed never really been there at all  perhaps shed just imagined it.   
(3) To think that something is true or may happen, but without being sure or having proof.
Example: a very complicated subject, i imagine,  said edwin.

Example: You can imagine how angry i was!  !

(1) A lack of a fair or correct balance between two things, which results in problems or unfairness.
Example: The government must redress the imbalance (= put it right ) in spending on black and white children.

(1) To drink something, especially alcohol – sometimes used humorously.
Example: Both men imbibed considerable quantities of gin. 
(2) To accept and be influenced by qualities, ideas, values etc.
Example: She had imbibed the traditions of her family.

(1) To copy the way someone behaves, speaks, moves etc, especially in order to make people laugh.

(1) When you copy someone else’s actions.

(3) A copy of something.
Example: She wore an imitation of a sailors hat.

(1) Happening or done at once and without delay.
Example: Our immediate response to the attack was sheer horror.

Example: Lets try and solve the most immediate problem . 
(3) Happening just before or just after someone or something else.
Example: The most immediate effect of retirement is a dramatic reduction in living standards. 
(4) Next to, or very near to, a particular place.
Example: It is a thriving shopping centre for the people who live in the immediate area . 
(5) People who are very closely related to you, such as your parents, children, brothers, and sisters.

(1) Without delay.
Example: Mix in the remaining ingredients and serve immediately. 
(2) Very soon before or after something.
Example: He retired immediately after the end of the war. 
(3) Able to be seen or understood very easily.

(4) Very near to something.
Example: The seat immediately behind the driver

(6) As soon as.
Example: Immediately you begin to speak, he gives you his full attention.

(1) Extremely large.
Example: People who travel by rail still read an immense amount.

(1) To put someone or something deep into a liquid so that they are completely covered.
Example: Immerse your foot in ice-cold water to reduce the swelling.

Example: He left school at 16 and immersed himself in the labour party.  16

(1) Someone who enters another country to live there permanently.

(2) Someone who comes from abroad to live permanently in another country.
Example: The country has a large immigrant population .

(1) To come into a country in order to live there permanently.
Example: His father and mother immigrated when he was two. 
(2) To come into a country in order to live there permanently.
Example: Born in the philippines, celeste immigrated to the united states when she was 15.

(3) The place at an airport, sea port etc where officials check the documents of everyone entering the country.
(4) The process of entering another country, state etc in order to live there.
Example: In the past, california has had the highest rate of immigration.
(5) The place at an airport, port etc where officials check the documents of people entering the country.

(1) An event that is imminent, especially an unpleasant one, will happen very soon.
Example: He was in imminent danger of dying.

(1) Not moving at all.
Example: She could see a figure sitting immobile, facing the sea. 
(2) Unable to move or walk normally.
Example: Kims illness had rendered her completely immobile.

(1) To prevent someone or something from moving.
Example: The broken limb must be immobilized immediately. 
(2) To stop something from working.
Example: The cars security device will immobilize the ignition system. 
(3) If a company immobilizes its capital, it uses it to buy capital goods (=machinery and equipment that is used to make other goods).
(4) If something immobilizes an organization, machine etc, it prevents it from working.
Example: A miners strike has immobilised all power plants.

(1) Someone who is immune to a particular disease cannot catch it.
Example: Once weve had the disease, were immune for life. 
(2) The reaction of the body’s immune system to something that is harmful.
Example: Hiv is a progressive disease which the immune response ultimately fails to control. 
(3) Not affected by something that happens or is done.
Example: The labour party is not immune to new ideas. 
(4) Specially protected from something unpleasant.
Example: The senior members of the group appeared to be immune from arrest.

(1) The system by which your body protects itself against disease.
Example: My immune system is not as strong as it ought to be.

(1) The state or right of being protected from particular laws or from unpleasant things.
Example: They were granted immunity from prosecution. 
(2) The state of being immune to a disease.
Example: Immunity to infection

(1) Never changing or impossible to change.
Example: This decision should not be seen as immutable.

(1) The effect or influence that an event, situation etc has on someone or something.
Example: We need to assess the impact on climate change. 
(2) The force of one object hitting another.
Example: The force of the impact knocked the breath out of her. 
(3) At the moment when one thing hits another.
Example: The planes wing was damaged on impact. 
(4) To have an important or noticeable effect on someone or something.
Example: The food safety act will progressively impact on the way food businesses operate. 
(5) The effect or influence that an event, situation etc has on someone or something.
Example: High interest rates have a negative impact on spending.
(6) To have an important or noticeable effect on someone or something.
Example: The recession has impacted the domestic business market.

(1) To damage something or make it not as good as it should be.
Example: The illness had impaired his ability to think and concentrate.

(1) To give a particular quality to something.
Example: Use a piece of fresh ginger to impart a far eastern flavour to simple ingredients. 
(2) To give information, knowledge, wisdom etc to someone.
Example: She had information that she couldnt wait to impart.

(1) Not involved in a particular situation, and therefore able to give a fair opinion or piece of advice.
Example: We offer impartial advice on tax and insurance.

(1) Not showing any emotion.
Example: Her impassive face showed no reaction at all.

(1) Without any faults and impossible to criticize.
Example: She has taught her children impeccable manners .

(1) Having very little money, especially over a long period – sometimes used humorously.
Example: He came from a respectable if impecunious family. 
(2) Having very little money.
Example: The university mainly caters for the most impecunious students who reach university level.

(1) To make it difficult for someone or something to move forward or make progress.

(1) A physical problem that makes speaking, hearing, or moving difficult.
Example: A speech impediment

(1) If something impels you to do something, it makes you feel very strongly that you must do it.
Example: The lack of democracy and equality impelled the oppressed to fight for independence.

(1) An impending event or situation, especially an unpleasant one, is going to happen very soon.

(1) Extremely important and needing to be done or dealt with immediately.
Example: It is imperative that politicians should be good communicators. 
(2) An imperative verb is one that expresses an order, such as ‘stand up’.
(3) Something that must be done urgently.
Example: A broad and balanced education is an imperative for raising standards. 
(4) An idea or belief that has a strong influence on people, making them behave in a particular way.
Example: Sharing food is the most important moral imperative in semai society. 
(5) The form of a verb that expresses an order. for example, in the order ‘come here’, ‘come’ is in the imperative..

(1) To put something or someone in danger.

(1) Giving orders and expecting to be obeyed, in a way that seems too proud.

(1) Not allowing liquids or gases to pass through.
Example: No paint is impermeable to water vapour.

(1) Not showing any feelings of sympathy, friendliness etc.

(2) A place or situation that is impersonal does not make people feel that they are important.
Example: I hate staying in hotels; theyre so impersonal. 
(3) In grammar, an impersonal sentence or verb is one where the subject is represented by ‘it’ or ‘there’, as in the sentence ‘it rained all day’.

(1) To pretend to be someone else by copying their appearance, voice, and behaviour, especially in order to deceive people.
Example: Do you know it is a very serious offence to impersonate a police officer? 
(2) To copy someone’s voice and behaviour, especially in order to make people laugh.
Example: In the film, he amusingly impersonates a woman.

(1) Rude and not respectful, especially to someone who is older or more important.

(1) Not affected or influenced by something and seeming not to notice it.

(2) Not allowing anything to enter or pass through.
Example: Impervious volcanic rock

(1) Tending to do things very quickly, without thinking carefully first, or showing this quality.
Example: He was high-spirited and impetuous.

(1) An influence that makes something happen or makes it happen more quickly.

(2) The force that makes an object start moving, or keeps it moving.

(1) To have a harmful effect on someone or something.

(1) Very determined to continue opposing someone or something.

(1) Difficult to believe and therefore unlikely to be true.

(1) To take action or make changes that you have officially decided should happen.

(1) To show or suggest that someone is involved in a crime or dishonest act.

(1) A possible future effect or result of an action, event, decision etc.

(1) Suggested or understood without being stated directly.

Example: They had implicit faith in his powers.

(1) To suggest that something is true, without saying this directly.

(3) If one thing implies another, it proves that the second thing exists.
Example: Democracy implies a respect for individual liberties.

(1) A product that is brought from one country into another so that it can be sold there, or the business of doing this.

(1) An important event, decision, problem etc has a big effect or influence on people’s lives or on events in the future.

(1) If someone in authority imposes a rule, punishment, tax etc, they force people to accept it.

(1) Large, impressive, and appearing important.

(1) Not clear or exact.

(1) To make someone feel admiration and respect.

(1) Something that is impressive makes you admire it because it is very good, large, important etc.

(1) To make something better, or to become better.

(1) The act of improving something, or the state of being improved.

(1) To do something without any preparation, because you are forced to do this by unexpected events.

(1) Rude and showing no respect to other people.

(1) A sudden strong desire to do something without thinking about whether it is a sensible thing to do.

Example: The eye converts light signals to nerve impulses. 
(3) A reason or aim that causes a particular kind of activity or behaviour.

(1) To say, often unfairly, that someone is responsible for something bad or has bad intentions.
Example: The police were not guilty of the violence imputed to them. 
(2) To suggest that someone or something is the cause of a particular situation, or is responsible for a particular action, especially something bad.
Example: The court ruled that the newspaper report did impute a criminal offense.
(3) To calculate the value of something which cannot easily be measured in the usual way by giving it a value based on similar things.
Example: The inland revenue imputes a set amount of taxable income according to the size of a company cars engine.
(4) If the interest on a loan is imputed to the loan agreement, the interest is calculated at market rates, even though the actual rate of interest paid may be lower than the market rates.

(1) Used with the name of a container, place, or area to say where someone or something is.

(2) Into a container, place etc.

Example: A room furnished in the modern style 
(4) Used with the names of months, years, seasons etc to say when something happens.
Example: 5 shaw was born in 1856. 1856

Example: It was amazing how much we managed to do in a day.
