Example: Ill be with you in a minute. 
(7) Used with negatives or with ‘first’ to say how much time has passed since the last time something happened.
Example: I havent enjoyed myself so much in years. 
(8) Used to name the book, document, film etc where something or someone appears.
Example: You shouldnt believe everything you read in the newspapers. 
(9) Making up the whole of something or included as part of something.
Example: There are twelve programmes in the series.  12 
(10) Doing or affecting a particular kind of job.
Example: A career in industry 
(11) Wearing something.
Example: He looked very handsome in his uniform. 
(12) Used to talk about the state or situation of something or someone.
Example: I hear that their marriage is in trouble. 
(13) Used to say what activity a group of people do.
Example: About 4,000 students took part in the protest.  4,000 
(14) Used to talk about the shape, arrangement, or course of something or someone.
Example: I want you all to stand in a circle. 
(15) Used between a smaller number and a larger number to say how common or how likely something is.
Example: One in ten homes now has cable tv. 
(16) Used before a plural number or amount to say how many people or things are involved, or how many there are in each group.
Example: Eggs are still sold in half dozens. 
(17) Used between a smaller number or amount and a larger one to say what a rate is.
Example: Income tax stands at 23 pence in the pound.  23 
(18) Used to say what colour something is or what it is made of.
Example: Do you have the same pattern in blue? 
(19) Used to say what specific thing your statement is related to.
Example: Milk is very rich in calcium. 
(20) Used to refer to the weather or the physical conditions somewhere.
Example: Ive been standing in the rain for over an hour. 
(21) Used to say what feeling you have when you do something.
Example: She looked at me in horror. 
(22) Used before the name of someone or something when you are saying how they are regarded.
Example: You have a very good friend in pat. 
(23) Used to say what person or thing has the quality you are mentioning.
Example: There was a hint of spring in the air. 
(24) Used to name the substance, food, drink etc that contains something.
Example: Vitamin d is found in butter.  d 
(25) Used to say how many parts something is divided into.
Example: A radio serial in four parts 
(26) While doing something or while something is happening, and as a result of this.
Example: In all the confusion, it is quite possible that some people got tickets without paying. 
(27) Used after a statement to begin to explain in what way it is true.
Example: Ive been lucky in that i have never had to worry about money. 
(28) To be between the ages of 20 and 29,30 and 39 etc.
Example: Matthews was already in his mid-40s. 
(29) Into or inside a container, place, vehicle etc.
Example: Eric held the boat steady while the children got in. 
(30) Inside or into a building, especially your home or the place where you work.
Example: Come in and sit down. 
(31) If a train, boat, or plane is in, it has arrived at a station, airport etc.
Example: Our trains not in yet. 
(32) Given or sent to a person or organization to be dealt with by them.
Example: All entries must be in by next week. 
(33) If you write, paint, or draw something in, you add it in the correct place.
Example: Fill in your name and address on the form provided.

Example: Agassis second serve was just in. 
(36) If a politician or a political party is in, they have been elected.
Example: Labour recorded its highest vote ever, but the tories got in again. 
(37) Towards the centre.
Example: The map had started to curl in at the edges.

Example: The tide was in, and the sea lapped against the harbour wall.

Example: Im afraid hes in for a bit of a disappointment. 
(40) If someone is in for it, they are going to be punished.
Example: If they find out what ive done, ill be in for it, wont i? 
(41) To be or become involved in something that is happening.
Example: I think you ought to be in on this discussion, ted. 
(42) To have a friendly relationship with someone.
Example: Shes in with the theatrical crowd. 
(43) To be present or involved when something starts.

Example: Red is definitely the in colour this year. 
(45) All the facts and details of something.
Example: The book guides you through the ins and outs of choosing and growing garden flowers. 
(46) A way of getting the opportunity to do something or influence someone.
Example: The job is pretty boring, but its an in to a career in publishing.

(7) A nominal figure, level etc is not the real one because something such as inflation has not been taken into account.

(1) Someone who is passive tends to accept things that happen to them or things that people say to them, without taking any action.

(1) To say that something will happen, before it happens.

(1) To like someone or something more than someone or something else, so that you would choose it if you could.

(1) A moral rule or belief about what is right and wrong, that influences how you behave.

Example: Pristine african rainforest

(1) The state of being able to be alone, and not seen or heard by other people.
Example: With seven people squashed in one house, you dont get much privacy. 
(2) The state of being free from public attention.
Example: Each individuals right to privacy

(1) For use by one person or group, not for everyone.
Example: Morris has a private jet. 
(2) Not related to, owned by, or paid for by the government.
Example: A private hospital 
(3) A private meeting, conversation etc involves only two people or a small number of people, and is not for other people to know about.
Example: I need to have a private discussion with you. 
(4) Private feelings, information, or opinions are personal or secret and not for other people to know about.
Example: Jacks private opinion was that she was selfish. 
(5) Used about someone who is not known to the public or not working for the government or another organization.
Example: A private citizen 
(6) Separate from and not related to your work or your official position.
Example: The president is paying a private visit to europe. 
(7) Quiet and without a lot of people.
Example: Why dont we go upstairs where its more private? 
(8) A private person is one who likes being alone, and does not talk much about their thoughts or feelings.
Example: Hes a very private man. 
(9) A joke made between friends, family members etc that other people do not understand.
(10) Without other people being present.
Example: I need to speak to you in private. 
(11) A soldier of the lowest rank.
(12) Private parts.
(13) Private property, businesses, activities etc are owned or paid for by people and companies, rather than the government.
Example: They transferred ownership of thousands of companies from the state to the private sector (= the part of the economy not owned by the government ) .
(14) Involving something that is sold directly to people or organizations, without being offered openly for anyone to buy.
Example: The company has raised $50 million in a private placement arranged by kemper financial services.
(15) Not belonging to the government.
Example: Slovak officials approved proposals to put 200 companies in private hands.
(16) Belonging to a member of the public rather than to an organization.
Example: There are more than 100 million handguns in private hands in the us.
(17) If a government-owned organization goes or turns private, it is sold to investors.
Example: Iberia airlines will be ready to go private next year.
(18) To pay for medical treatment instead of getting it free at a public hospital.
(19) A private company does not make its shares available for anyone to buy on a stockmarket.
Example: Cargill, the largest private company in the us, wants to stay that way. says mr west, a vice president: well go public (= sell shares on the stockmarket ) the week after snowballs form in hell.
(20) If a company with shares on the stockmarket goes private, its owners buy back those shares from existing shareholders so that it becomes privately owned.
Example: The majority of companies that went private in the last few years will become public again by reselling stock.
(21) If a company’s owners take it private, they buy back all shares from existing shareholders.
Example: The companys chairman plans to take the company private through a buy-out of the 74% of shares he doesnt already own.
(22) Only for use by one particular person or group, not for everyone.
Example: A private road
(23) A private meeting, agreement, conversation etc involves only a small number of people and is kept secret.
Example: Mr. miscio rose to protest, saying this is a private meeting.

(1) A lack or loss of the things that everyone needs, such as food, warmth, and shelter.
Example: The privations of wartime

(1) A special advantage that is given only to one person or group of people.
Example: He had no special privileges and was treated just like every other prisoner. 
(2) Something that you are lucky to have the chance to do, and that you enjoy very much.
Example: Today, we have the privilege of listening to two very unusual men. 
(3) A situation in which people who are rich or of a high social class have many more advantages than other people.
Example: Wealth and privilege 
(4) A situation in which doctors, lawyers etc are allowed to keep information about their discussions with their patients or clients secret from other people.
(5) The right to do or say something unacceptable without being punished, especially in parliament.
(6) To treat some people or things better than others.
(7) A special advantage given to a small group of people, organizations, countries etc.
Example: The new trade privileges will enhance viennas effort to attract us companies.
(8) A right in law that protects a person, for example by not forcing them to discuss something, or allowing them freedom to say things that would not normally be acceptable.
Example: Ms. backiel asserted the attorney-client privilege and refused to discuss the case.

(1) How likely something is, sometimes calculated in a mathematical way.
Example: The probability of winning the lottery is really very low. 
(2) What is likely or something that is likely.
Example: The probability is that smaller businesses will not have to pay the tax. 
(3) Very probably.
Example: Mistakes could and, in all probability, would occur. 
(4) The chance that something will happen, calculated mathematically.
Example: Companies may collaborate (= work together ) in working out loss probabilities.

(1) Likely to exist, happen, or be true.
Example: The probable cause of the fire was faulty wiring. 
(2) Someone who is likely to be chosen for a team, to win a race etc.

(1) A system that allows some criminals not to go to prison or to leave prison, if they behave well and see a probation officer regularly, for a particular period of time.
Example: The judge sentenced jennings to three years probation. 
(2) A period of time, during which an employer can see if a new worker is suitable.
Example: A three-month probation period 
(3) A period of time in which you must improve your work or behave well so that you will not have to leave your job.
Example: Im afraid i have no choice but to put you on probation . 
(4) A period of time during which a new employee is tested to make sure they are suitable for a job.
Example: At the end of the year i can pass or fail or have my probation extended.
(5) A fixed period of time during which a person or company must improve their performance if they are to continue working, trading etc.
Example: Calpers said it was placing salomon on probation, meaning it could sever all its business ties with the firm.
(6) A system of dealing with criminals which allows them not to go to prison, if they behave well and see an official adviser regularly, for a fixed period of time.
Example: Two of the accused were sentenced to prison terms, and the third received 10 months probation.

(1) To ask questions in order to find things out, especially things that other people do not want you to know.
Example: I dont want to probe too deeply into your personal affairs. 
(2) To look for something or examine something, using a long thin object.
Example: Jules probed the mud gingerly with a stick. 
(3) A long thin metal instrument that doctors and scientists use to examine parts of the body.
(4) A space probe.
(5) An investigation in which many questions are asked to discover the truth about something.
Example: A police corruption probe 
(6) A very thorough examination of something that has happened.
Example: The probe focuses on an unauthorized bid placed by the company two months ago.
(7) To ask very detailed questions to find something out, especially things people do not want you to know.
Example: To probe further, i called economist john mueller.

(1) Complete honesty.
Example: I have always found bentner to be a model of probity in our dealings. 
(2) Honesty and correctness.
Example: An accountant provides assurance of fiscal probity to businesses.

(1) A situation that causes difficulties.
Example: She was older than me, but that wasnt really a problem. 
(2) Something wrong with your health or with part of your body.
Example: Does she have any long-term health problems? 
(3) A question for which you have to find the right answer, using mathematics or careful thought.
Example: She gave us 20 mathematical problems to solve.  20 
(4) Used to say that you are happy to do something or for someone else to do something.
Example: can i bring a friend? sure, no problem.     
(5) To do something easily.
Example: Ive had no problem recruiting staff. 
(6) Used before saying what the main difficulty in a situation is.
Example: The problem is, there isnt enough time. 
(7) Used to say rudely that someone else is responsible for dealing with a situation, not you.
Example: If you miss the train, thats your problem. 
(8) Used to say rudely that you are not responsible for dealing with a particular problem and are not willing to help.
Example: weve got a serious staffing shortage. thats not my problem.     
(9) Used when you think that someone is behaving in a way that is unreasonable.
(10) Used to ask someone why they seem to disagree with you, in a way that shows that you are annoyed.
(11) A child etc whose behaviour causes problems for other people.

(1) A way of doing something, especially the correct or usual way.
Example: Whats the procedure for applying for a visa? 
(2) A medical treatment or operation.
Example: Liposuction is a minor surgical procedure . 
(3) The official or accepted way of doing something, especially something that is done often.
Example: We have hired an accounting firm to evaluate our audit procedures.

(1) To continue to do something that has already been planned or started.
Example: The government was determined to proceed with the election. 
(2) To continue.
Example: Work is proceeding according to plan . 
(3) To do something after doing something else first – used sometimes to express surprise or annoyance.
Example: Sammy took off his coat and proceeded to undo his boots. 
(4) To move in a particular direction.
Example: Passengers for miami should proceed to gate 25.  25 
(5) To begin a legal case against someone.
(6) To happen or exist as a result of something.
Example: Ideas that proceed from a disturbed state of mind 
(7) If you proceed to the next part of an activity, job etc, you do or take part in the next part of it.
Example: Players who proceed to the finals of the competition 
(8) To continue to do something that has been started.
Example: The discussions between the two firms are proceeding slowly but satisfactorily.

(1) An event or a series of things that happen.
Example: We watched the proceedings in the street below. 
(2) When someone uses a court of law to deal with a legal case.
Example: She has begun divorce proceedings . 
(3) The official written records of a meeting, society etc.
Example: The proceedings of the conference

(1) The money that is obtained from doing something or selling something.
Example: We sold the business and bought a villa in spain with the proceeds. 
(2) The money gained from selling something.
Example: Allied-signal was planning to use the proceeds from the sale of union texas to reduce debt.
(3) The money that a business gets from issuing (=selling) bonds, shares etc.
Example: San diego will use the proceeds from the bond issue to acquire and install new police facilities.

(1) A series of actions that are done in order to achieve a particular result.
Example: The israeliegyptian peace process 
(2) A series of things that happen naturally and result in gradual change.
Example: The natural process of evolution 
(3) To have started doing something and not yet be finished.
Example: The company is in the process of moving to new offices. 
(4) If something is in process, it is happening now.
Example: There was an armed revolt in process. 
(5) While you are doing something or something is happening.
Example: I spilt the coffee, burning myself in the process. 
(6) A way of finding the right answer, the truth etc by gradually deciding that none of the other answers etc are possible.
Example: I solved the problem by a process of elimination. 
(7) A method of making or producing goods.
Example: The car production process 
(8) To make food, materials, or goods ready to be used or sold, for example by preserving or improving them in some way.
Example: Goats cheese may be processed in many ways. 
(9) To deal with an official document, request etc in the usual way.
Example: All university applications are processed through this system. 
(10) To deal with information using a computer.
Example: The new network will enable data to be processed more speedily. 
(11) To print a picture from a photographic film.
(12) To walk or move along in a very slow and serious way, especially as part of a group.
(13) A series of actions taken to perform a particular task or achieve a particular result.
Example: Simpler design and manufacturing processes
(14) To have started doing something that is not yet finished.
Example: General motors is in the process of beginning discussions with potential partners.
(15) To change a substance as part of the manufacture of a product.
Example: The refineries are processing 1.4 million barrels of crude oil a day.
(16) To deal with a document in the usual way.
Example: The service was started to help process copyright permissions more rapidly.
(17) If a computer processes information, figures etc, it uses them to produce a particular result.
Example: The accounts are processed by the systems union sun account system.

(1) A line of people or vehicles moving slowly as part of a ceremony.
Example: They marched in procession to the capitol building. 
(2) Several people or things of the same type, appearing or happening one after the other.
Example: An endless procession of visitors

(1) The central part of a computer that deals with the commands and information it is given.
(2) A machine or person that processes food or other materials before they are sold or used.
Example: Us tuna processors 
(3) The central part of a computer that does the calculations on the information put into it.
Example: An intel pentium iii processor
(4) A company that prepares substances, especially food, for sale or as part of another product.
Example: Georgia officials blocked sales by an atlanta milk processor after detecting contamination in its milk.

(1) To say publicly or officially that something important is true or exists.
Example: The president proclaimed the republics independence. 
(2) To show something clearly or be a sign of something.
Example: The stripes on her uniform proclaimed her seniority.

(1) A tendency to behave in a particular way, or to like a particular thing – used especially about something bad.
Example: The child showed no proclivity towards aggression.

(1) To delay doing something that you ought to do, usually because you do not want to do it.
Example: People often procrastinate when it comes to paperwork.

(1) To obtain something, especially something that is difficult to get.
Example: He was accused of procuring weapons for terrorists. 
(2) To provide a prostitute for someone.
(3) To obtain something that is needed for a particular task.
Example: Companies in the industry reported difficulty in procuring raw materials.

(1) To quickly push something or someone with your finger or a pointed object.
Example: dont go to sleep,  she said, prodding me in the ribs.    
(2) To make someone do something by persuading or reminding them that it is necessary, especially when they are lazy or unwilling.
Example: It had prodded ben into doing something about it. 
(3) A quick pushing movement, using your finger or a pointed object.
Example: go on,  he whispered, giving me a prod in the back.    
(4) When you persuade or remind someone to do something.
Example: Why dont you ring the shop and give them a prod ? 
(5) A pointed instrument used for pushing animals, to make them move.
Example: A cattle prod

(1) Very large or great in a surprising or impressive way.
Example: Some galaxies seem to release prodigious amounts of energy.

(1) A young person who has a great natural ability in a subject or skill.
Example: Mozart was a musical prodigy.

(1) To cause a particular result or effect.
Example: New drugs are producing remarkable results . 
(2) To make, write etc something to be bought, used, or enjoyed by people.
Example: The factory produces an incredible 100 cars per hour.  100 
(3) To grow something or make it naturally.
Example: This region produces the grapes used in champagne. 
(4) If you produce an object, you bring it out or present it, so that people can see or consider it.
Example: When challenged, he produced a gun. 
(5) If someone produces a film or play, they find the money for it and control the way it is made.
Example: Costner produced and directed the film. 
(6) To give birth to a baby or young animals.
Example: An adult cat may produce kittens three times a year. 
(7) Food or other things that have been grown or produced on a farm to be sold.
Example: Fresh local produce 
(8) Food that has been grown on the land or produced in large quantities, using farming methods.
Example: Where it once offered 125 items of produce, a&p now sells 300 fruits and vegetables.
(9) To make or grow something in large quantities to be sold.
Example: The plant in leningrad will produce parts used in building construction.
(10) To make something happen or to have a particular result or effect.
Example: A strong market could mean sales will produce substantial profit gains.
(11) To control the preparation of a film, television programme etc, especially the amount of money spent making it.
Example: Disneys computer-animated film will be produced by pixar.
(12) To show an official document when it is needed, for example as proof of something.
Example: The judge ordered officials to produce financial records within three days.

(1) Producing or achieving a lot.
Example: Most of us are more productive in the morning. 
(2) Relating to the production of goods, crops, or wealth.
Example: The economys productive capacity 
(3) Causing or resulting in something.
Example: The meeting was productive of several good ideas. 
(4) Producing or achieving something.
Example: The program is designed to help business users be more productive.
(5) Producing crops, goods, or wealth.
Example: The strike is cutting deeper into the companys productive capacity (= ability to produce things ) .

(1) The rate at which goods are produced, and the amount produced, especially in relation to the work, time, and money needed to produce them.
Example: Ways of increasing productivity 
(2) The rate at which goods are produced, and the amount produced in relation to the work, time, and money needed to produce them.
Example: Declines in factory jobs and hours worked mean that only more productivity per worker could have raised output in may.

(1) Showing a lack of respect for god or holy things.
Example: Profane language 
(2) Related to ordinary life, not religion or holy things.
Example: Sacred and profane art 
(3) To treat something holy with a lack of respect.

(1) A job that needs a high level of education and training.
Example: Members of the teaching profession 
(2) All the people who work in a particular profession.
Example: The medical profession 
(3) A statement of your belief, opinion, or feeling.
Example: A profession of faith 
(4) The job of being a prostitute – used humorously.
(5) A job that needs advanced education and special training.
Example: Realtors, a profession with an established record of service to the public
(6) Used to talk about the people working in a particular job, considered as separate groups.
Example: In the bankruptcy field you find some of the legal professions most forceful personalities.
(7) Accountants, doctors, lawyers, teachers etc considered as one group.
Example: During this century, the professions have been one of the fastest growing sectors of the occupational structure.
(8) If someone is a doctor, teacher etc by profession, that is what they trained to do as their job. this phrase is usually used when talking about the fact that someone is doing different work for a period of time.
Example: A graphic designer by profession, he has spent the last two years in public relations.

(1) Relating to a job that needs special education and training.
Example: What professional qualifications does he have? 
(2) Showing that someone has been well trained and is good at their work.
Example: This business plan looks very professional. 
(3) Doing a job, sport, or activity for money, rather than just for fun.
Example: A professional tennis player 
(4) Done by or relating to people who are paid to do a sport or activity.
Example: A professional hockey team 
(5) Someone who works in a profession, or who has an important position in a company or business.
Example: Wed prefer to rent the house to a professional couple. 
(6) Someone who lies or complains too much – used humorously.
(7) Someone who earns money by doing a job, sport, or activity that many other people do just for fun.
Example: Hurd signed as a professional in 1998.  1998 
(8) Someone who works in a job that needs special education and training, such as a doctor, lawyer, or architect.
Example: Health professionals (= doctors, nurses etc ) 
(9) Someone who has a lot of experience and does something very skilfully.
Example: You sing like a real professional. 
(10) Someone who is very good at a sport and is employed by a private club to teach its members.
(11) Connected with a job requiring advanced education and special training.
Example: Professional qualifications
(12) Training offered to people working in professions as part of their job.
Example: The law societys continuing professional development scheme
(13) Very well trained and showing high standards of work.
Example: The women made an excellent showing  they were every bit as professional as their male colleagues.
(14) Doing an activity, sport etc to earn money, rather than for pleasure.
Example: A professional footballer
(15) Someone who does a job requiring advanced education and special training.
Example: A number of market professionals are recommending cyclical stocks.
(16) Someone who is very experienced, has a lot of knowledge, and does things very skilfully.
Example: The successful applicant will be a decisive professional, capable of making hard decisions.
(17) Someone who earns money doing a job, sport etc that other people do for pleasure.
Example: Nike say the shoe is designed for professionals and advanced amateurs (= people who do a sport for pleasure ) .

(1) The skill and high standards of behaviour expected of a professional person.
Example: The dedication and professionalism of our staff 
(2) The practice of using professional players in sports.
Example: Professionalism has raised the standard of rugby immensely.

(1) A good standard of ability and skill.
Example: A high level of proficiency in english 
(2) A high standard of skill in a particular job or knowledge of a particular subject.
Example: One corporation spends $2,000 a quarter bringing its employees up to technical proficiency .

(1) Able to do something well or skilfully.
Example: Marthas proficient in swedish. 
(2) Able to do something skilfully and well.
Example: As standards rise, less proficient pilots wont be hired.

(1) A side view of someone’s head.
Example: Dani has a lovely profile. 
(2) A short description that gives important details about a person, a group of people, or a place.
Example: A job profile 
(3) Something that is high profile is noticed by many people or gets a lot of attention.
Example: Jack runs a department with a high public profile. 
(4) To behave quietly and avoid doing things that will make people notice you.
(5) If a person or an organization raises its profile, it gets more attention from the public.
Example: An advertising campaign designed to raise the banks profile 
(6) An edge or a shape of something seen against a background.
Example: The sharp profile of the western foothills against the sky 
(7) To write or give a short description of someone or something.
Example: The new chief executive was profiled in yesterdays newspaper. 
(8) A short description of someone or something, giving the most important details about them.
Example: A profile of the company in the latest edition of barrons contributed to interest in the stock.
(9) Used to talk about how much things are noticed and the degree to which they are given attention.
Example: The bank wants to raise its profile (= become better known ) as an asset manager for wealthier individuals.
(10) To give a short description of someone or something in a newspaper, television programme etc.
Example: The stock was favorably profiled in fridays edition of investors daily.

(1) Money that you gain by selling things or doing business, after your costs have been paid.
Example: The shops daily profit is usually around $500.  500 
(2) An advantage that you gain from doing something.
Example: Theres no profit in letting meetings drag on. 
(3) To be useful or helpful to someone.
Example: It might profit you to learn about the company before your interview. 
(4) To get money from doing something.
Example: Some industries, such as shipbuilding, clearly profited from the war. 
(5) Money that you gain from selling something, or from doing business in a particular period of time, after taking away costs.
Example: A business has to make a profit .
(6) Profits for the first three-month period, second six-month period etc of the financial year.
Example: The insurer recorded fourth-quarter profit of 86 cents a share, compared with year-earlier net income of 82 cents.
(7) To gain money from an event, selling something etc.
Example: Tiger profited by anticipating the fall in the tokyo stock market.

(1) Producing a profit or a useful result.
Example: The advertising campaign proved very profitable. 
(2) Producing a useful result.
Example: I thought the meeting was very profitable.
(3) Producing a profit.
Example: Innovation has made sidek one of mexicos most profitable companies .

(1) Wasting money or other things in a careless way.
Example: Profligate spending 
(2) Behaving in an immoral way and not caring that your behaviour is bad.

(1) Having a strong influence or effect.
Example: Tolstoys experiences of war had a profound effect on his work. 
(2) Showing strong serious feelings.
Example: A profound sense of guilt 
(3) Showing great knowledge and understanding.
Example: A profound question 
(4) Deep or far below the surface of something.
Example: Her work touches something profound in the human psyche. 
(5) Complete.
Example: Profound deafness

(1) Produced or existing in large quantities.
Example: He made profuse apologies .

(1) The process of getting better at doing something, or getting closer to finishing or achieving something.
Example: The police are disappointed by the slow progress of the investigation. 
(2) Slow or steady movement somewhere.
Example: We made good progress despite the snow. 
(3) Change which is thought to lead to a better society, because of developments in science or fairer methods of social organization.
Example: Mankind is destroying the planet, all in the name of progress (= because people want progress ) . 
(4) Happening now, and not yet finished.
Example: A lecture was in progress in the main hall. 
(5) To improve, develop, or achieve things so that you are then at a more advanced stage.
Example: I asked the nurse how my son was progressing. 
(6) If an activity such as work or a project progresses, or you progress it, it continues.
Example: Work on the ship progressed quickly. 
(7) If time or an event progresses, time passes.
Example: As the meeting progressed, nina grew more and more bored. 
(8) To move forward.
Example: Our taxi seemed to be progressing very slowly. 
(9) To develop over a period of time, becoming better or more complete.
Example: The joint venture is progressing faster than expected.
(10) If a situation progresses, it continues to happen.
Example: As the afternoon progressed, prices nosed upward in light trading.
(11) The process of improving something, or getting closer to finishing it.
Example: The company has made significant financial progress this year.
(12) If a plan, project etc is in progress, it has started but is not finished yet.
Example: There are only faint signs that an economic recovery is in progress.

(1) A gradual process of change or development.
Example: The natural progression of the disease 
(2) A number of things coming one after the other.
(3) Gradual development and improvement over a period of time.
Example: The typical career progression includes two years of technical training.

(1) Supporting new or modern ideas and methods, especially in politics and education.
Example: A progressive administration 
(2) Happening or developing gradually over a period of time.
Example: The progressive increase in population 
(3) The progressive form of a verb is used to show that an action or activity is continuing to happen. in english, it consists of the verb ‘be’ followed by the present participle, as in ‘i was waiting for the bus’..
(4) Someone with modern ideas who wants to change things.
(5) Happening or changing over a period of time, and often becoming worse.
Example: The results reflect the progressive collapse of sales of the companys high-end computers.
(6) Supporting new or modern ideas, methods etc.
Example: He begam his career as a progressive economist before becoming prime minister at the age of 40.

(1) To say that an action is illegal or not allowed.
Example: Smoking is strictly prohibited inside the factory. 
(2) To make something impossible or prevent it from happening.
(3) To officially stop someone doing something by making it illegal or against the rules.
Example: The firms own internal rules now prohibit that type of loan.

(1) Prohibitive costs are so high that they prevent people from buying or doing something.
Example: The cost of land in tokyo is prohibitive. 
(2) A prohibitive rule prevents people from doing things.
Example: Prohibitive regulations 
(3) Prohibitive costs, prices etc are very high, and people cannot afford them.
Example: Given the resources of small companies, marketing costs can be prohibitive .

(1) A carefully planned piece of work to get information about something, to build something, to improve something etc.
Example: The project aims to provide an analysis of childrens emotions. 
(2) A part of a school or college course that involves careful study of a particular subject over a period of time.
Example: Were doing a project on pollution. 
(3) A housing project.
(4) To calculate what something will be in the future, using the information you have now.
Example: The company projected an annual growth rate of 3%.  3% 
(5) To stick out beyond an edge or surface.
Example: Four towers projected from the main building. 
(6) To make the picture of a film, photograph etc appear in a larger form on a screen or flat surface.
Example: She projected the slide onto the wall. 
(7) To try to make other people have a particular idea about you.
Example: I hope the team will project a smart professional image . 
(8) To be planned to happen in the future.
Example: The projected closure of the hospital 
(9) To speak clearly and loudly so that you can be heard by everyone in a big room.
(10) To make something move up or forwards with great force.
Example: The plant projects its seeds over a wide area. 
(11) To make someone quickly have success or a much better job.
Example: His success projected him onto channel 4s comedy series packet of three'. 
(12) To imagine that someone else is feeling the same emotions as you.
Example: Youre projecting your insecurity onto me. 
(13) An important and carefully planned piece of work that will create something new or improve a situation.
Example: The countrys largest ever construction project
(14) Money needed for a large building project, usually in the form of investment loans.
Example: Olympia & york developments ltd. is negotiating long-term project financing for its canary wharf development in london.
(15) To calculate what the size, amount, or rate of something will be in the future.
Example: California microwave dropped 2 points after it projected earnings of 19 cents a share for the third quarter.

(1) A statement or calculation about what something will be in the future or was in the past, based on information available now.
Example: Projections of declining natural gas production 
(2) Something that sticks out from a surface.
Example: Small projections of weathered rock on the hillside 
(3) The act of projecting a film or picture onto a screen.
Example: Projection equipment 
(4) The act of imagining that someone else is feeling the same emotions as you.
(5) A representation of something solid on a flat surface.
Example: A map projection 
(6) Something that you imagine to have particular qualities because of your wishes or feelings.
Example: The devil is a projection of our fears and insecurities. 
(7) A statement or calculation about what you think will happen in the future, based on the information that you have available now.
Example: The latest projections for growth in us gdp

(1) Something that you do to achieve something or deal with a situation, or the act of doing it.
Example: We may conclude that he never had recourse to this simple experiment. 
(2) Something that you can use to help you in a difficult situation.
Example: Partnership holders often find they have little recourse (= not much can be done to help them ) when the value of their investment plummets.
(3) The right of someone who has made a loan to take assets belonging to the borrower if the loan is not repaid, in addition to the asset on which the loan is secured.
Example: The finance company will often require the dealer to enter into a recourse agreement.
(4) The right of someone who holds a bill of exchange that is not paid when it becomes due to claim payment from people who have signed the bill, unless the words ‘without recourse’ have been written next to the signatures.

(1) To get better after an illness, accident, shock etc.
Example: After a few days of fever, she began to recover. 
(2) To return to a normal condition after a period of trouble or difficulty.
Example: The tourist industry is recovering to pre-war levels. 
(3) To get back something that was taken from you, lost, or almost destroyed.
Example: Four paintings stolen from the gallery have been recovered. 
(4) To get back an amount of money that you have spent or lost.
Example: He was entitled to recover damages from the defendants. 
(5) To get back an ability, a sense, or control over your feelings, movements etc after a period without it.
Example: It was some hours before she recovered consciousness . 
(6) To increase or improve after falling in value or getting worse.
Example: Its shares plunged at the start of trading, but recovered to close only slightly down.
(7) To get back money that you have spent or lost.
Example: The firm sued mr yasutomi and has recovered about one-third of its loss.
(8) To get back something that was stolen, lost, or almost destroyed.
Example: The fbi recovered over 100 stolen items from his apartment.
(9) To be paid money by order of a court of law.
Example: To recover damages against a teacher, a student must be able to show that it was the teachers negligence that caused the injury.
(10) If someone recovers oil, gold etc, they take it from under the ground or sea.
Example: They plan to recover 35 million barrels of oil from the two fields over six years.

(1) To make something from the past exist again in a new form or be experienced again.
Example: You can never recreate the feeling of winning for the first time.

(1) An activity that you do for pleasure or amusement.
Example: His only recreations are drinking beer and watching football.

(1) To find new people to work in a company, join an organization, do a job etc.

Example: Most of the men in the village were recruited that day.

Example: I recruited three of my friends to help me move. 
(4) Someone who has just joined the army, navy, or air force.
Example: Drill sergeants have eight weeks to turn fresh recruits into soldiers. 
(5) Someone who has recently joined an organization, team, group of people etc.
Example: New recruits are sent to the atlanta office for training. 
(6) To find new people to work for an organization, do a job etc.
Example: So far, they have recruited 10 new sales representatives.
(7) Someone who has recently joined a company or organization.
Example: A new recruit
(1) A shape that has four straight sides, two of which are usually longer than the other two, and four 90° angles at the corners.
(1) Having the shape of a rectangle.

(1) To correct something that is wrong.

(2) To correct something that is wrong.
Example: We apologise for the delay and are doing everything we can to rectify the situation.
(1) Behaviour that is honest and morally correct.

(1) If something, especially something bad or unpleasant, recurs, it happens again.
Example: There is a danger that the disease may recur. 
(2) If a number or numbers after a decimal point recur, they are repeated for ever in the same order.

(1) To put used objects or materials through a special process so that they can be used again.
Example: We take all our bottles to be recycled. 
(2) To use something such as an idea, writing etc again instead of developing something new.
Example: The fashion world just keeps recycling old ideas. 
(3) To put used objects or materials through a special process, so that they can be used again.
Example: We recycle all our cans and bottles.

(1) To make something less bad.

Example: He spent the rest of the game trying to redeem himself after a first-minute mistake. 
(3) To exchange a piece of paper representing an amount of money for that amount of money or for goods equal in cost to that amount of money.
Example: You can redeem the coupon at any store. 
(4) To free someone from the power of evil, especially in the christian religion.
(5) To do what you promised to do.
Example: The government found itself unable to redeem its election pledges. 
(6) To buy back something which you left with someone you borrowed money from.
Example: He finally redeemed his watch from the pawnbroker. 
(7) To pay off a loan or debt.
Example: He intends to redeem the mortgage at the earliest opportunity.
(8) To exchange shares, bonds etc for cash.
Example: A company will not normally be allowed to redeem its shares during the offer period if its board believes that a takeover offer is imminent.
(9) To get back something that you pawned (=left with someone when you borrowed money from them), by returning the money borrowed.

(1) The act of redeveloping an area, especially in a city.
Example: Redevelopment of the citys downtown area 
(2) When an area is improved by removing the buildings that are there and building new ones.

(1) To use something for a different purpose.

Example: We are redirecting funds to other departments.

Example: All mail will be redirected to our new offices.

(1) Someone who is redoubtable is a person you respect or fear.

(1) To make something smaller or less in size, amount, or price.

Example: She was reduced to tears in front of her students. 
(6) To make someone cry, be silent etc.
Example: She was reduced to tears in front of her students. 
(7) To make someone do something they would rather not do, especially when it involves behaving or living in a way that is not as good as before.
Example: Eventually charlotte was reduced to begging on the streets. 
(8) To destroy something, especially a building, completely.
Example: A massive earthquake reduced the city to rubble. 
(9) To change something into a shorter simpler form.
Example: Many jobs can be reduced to a few simple points. 
(10) To make something less or smaller in price, amount, or size.
Example: Jobs have been cut in order to reduce costs .

(1) If you are redundant, your employer no longer has a job for you.

(2) Not necessary because something else means or does the same thing.

(3) If you are made redundant, you lose your job because your employer no longer has a job for you.
Example: The bank expects to make 15,000 staff redundant over the next three years.

(1) A type of tall plant like grass that grows in wet places.

(2) A thin piece of wood that is attached to a musical instrument such as an oboe or clarinet, and that produces a sound when you blow over it.

(1) A line of sharp rocks, often made of coral, or a raised area of sand near the surface of the sea.

(2) To tie up part of a sail in order to make it smaller.

(1) To be confused or shocked by a situation.

(2) To step backwards suddenly and almost fall over, especially after being hit or getting a shock.

(3) To walk in an unsteady way and almost fall over, as if you are drunk.

(4) To seem to go around and around.
Example: The room reeled before my eyes and i fainted. 
(5) To wind the reel on a fishing rod so that a fish caught on the line comes towards you.
Example: It took almost an hour to reel the fish in. 
(6) To wind the reel on a fishing rod so that a fish caught on the line comes towards you.
Example: It took almost an hour to reel the fish in. 
(7) To get or attract a large number of people or things.
Example: The programme reels in more than 13 million viewers a show.  1,300 
(8) To repeat a lot of information quickly and easily.
Example: Jack reeled off a list of names. 
(9) To repeat a lot of information quickly and easily.
Example: Jack reeled off a list of names. 
(10) To do something again and again.
Example: The yankees reeled off 14 straight wins.  14 
(11) A round object onto which film, wire, a special string for fishing etc can be wound.
Example: A cotton reel

Example: The final reel 
(13) A quick folk dance, especially one from scotland or ireland, or the music for this.
(1) A large room in a school, college etc where meals are served and eaten.

(1) To mention or speak about someone or something.
Example: We agreed never to refer to the matter again. 
(2) To mention or speak about someone or something.
Example: We agreed never to refer to the matter again. 
(3) To look at a book, map, piece of paper etc for information.
Example: He gave the speech without referring to his notes. 
(4) If a statement, number, report etc refers to someone or something, it is about that person or thing.
Example: The figures refer to our sales in europe. 
(5) To send someone or something to a person or organization to be helped or dealt with.

(1) Someone who makes sure that the rules of a sport such as football, basketball, or boxing, are followed.

Example: His headmaster agreed to act as his referee. 
(3) Someone who is asked to settle a disagreement.
(4) Someone who judges an article or research idea before it is published or money is provided for it.
(5) To be the referee of a game.
(6) A person who provides information about your character, abilities, or qualifications when you are trying to get a job.
Example: Applications should be in the form of a cv and include the names of three referees.
(7) A person or organization named on a bill of exchange as a ‘referee in case of need’ and from whom the person holding the bill may demand payment if the bill is not paid or accepted.

(1) Part of something you say or write in which you mention a person or thing.
Example: There is no direct reference to her own childhood in the novel. 
(2) The act of looking at something for information.
Example: A vocabulary index is included for easy reference. 
(3) An idea, fact, event etc that you already know, which helps you understand or make a judgment about another situation.
Example: Lees case will be the reference point for lawyers in tomorrows trial. 
(4) Used to say what you are writing or talking about, especially in business letters.
Example: I am writing to you in reference to the job opening in your department. 
(5) A letter containing information about you that is written by someone who knows you well, and is usually intended for a new employer.
Example: We will need references from your former employers. 
(6) A book, article etc from which information has been obtained.
Example: A comprehensive list of references 
(7) A number that tells you where you can find the information you want in a book, on a map etc.
Example: A list of towns, each with a map reference 
(8) To mention another book, article etc that contains information connected with the subject you are writing about.
Example: The book does not reference anything written in the last 10 years. 
(9) Used to say what you are writing or talking about, especially in business letters.
Example: With reference to your recent advertisement, i am writing to apply for the post of sales manager.
(10) A group of numbers and letters that identify a document. a reference is often put at the top of a business letter.
Example: Thank you for your letter (reference jc/216).
(11) A letter written by someone who knows you well, usually to a new employer, giving information about your character, abilities, or qualifications.
Example: We will be taking up (= getting ) references from your former employers.

Example: Could i ask you to act as one of my references?

Example: Bank references are sought by companies to ensure that those with whom they are trading are solvent and can pay for the goods supplied to them.
(14) The agreed limits of what an official committee or report will deal with.
Example: The matter of compensation is not within the committees terms of reference.

(1) To improve a method, plan, system etc by gradually making slight changes to it.

(2) To make a substance purer using an industrial process.

(1) A substance that is refined has been made pure by an industrial process.

Example: A refined way of speaking 
(3) A method or process that is refined has been improved to make it more effective.
Example: Laser surgery has become much more refined over the last decade.

(1) An improvement, usually a small one, to something.

Example: Some further refinement is needed.

(1) An image that you can see in a mirror, glass, or water.

(1) A change or changes made to a system or organization in order to improve it.

Example: Plans to radically reform the tax system 
(3) To change your behaviour and become a better person, or to make someone do this.
Example: Greeley says hes a genuinely reformed character .

Example: The government has announced its plans to reform the tax system.

Example: Radical reforms of the company taxation system

(1) Someone who works to improve a social or political system.

(1) If glass or water refracts light, the light changes direction when it passes through the glass or water.

(1) To not do something that you want to do.

(3) A remark or idea that is often repeated.
Example: Our proposal met with the constant refrain that the company could not afford it.

(1) To make someone feel less tired or less hot.

(5) To make your computer screen show any new information that has arrived while you have been looking at a particular website etc.

(1) Making you feel less tired or less hot.
Example: A refreshing drink

Example: It made a refreshing change to talk to someone new.

(1) Small amounts of food and drink that are provided at a meeting, sports event etc.

Example: We worked all day without refreshment.

(1) To make something such as food or liquid cold in a refrigerator in order to preserve it.

(1) An amount of money that is given back to you if you are not satisfied with the goods or services that you have paid for.

(1) To decorate and repair something such as a building or office in order to improve its appearance.

Example: We need to give students plenty of positive reinforcement .

(1) To repeat a statement or opinion in order to make your meaning as clear as possible.

(1) To make something work much better or become much better again.

(4) To pay back money that has been borrowed.
Example: The funds will be used to repay short-term debt .

(1) To say or write something again.
Example: Can you repeat your question? 
(2) To do something again.
Example: Repeat the exercises twice a day. 
(3) To say something that someone else has just said, especially in order to learn it.
Example: Repeat after me: amo, amas, amat ...  amo  amas  amat 
(4) To tell someone something that you have heard, especially something secret.
Example: Heres what happened, but dont repeat it. 
(5) To broadcast a television or radio programme again.
Example: The series will be repeated in the autumn. 
(6) Used to say that you do not want to repeat what someone has said, especially because it is rude.
Example: Her comments dont bear repeating! 
(7) If food repeats on you, its taste keeps coming back into your mouth after you have eaten it.
(8) An event that is very like something that happened before.
Example: The match was basically a repeat of last years game at wembley. 
(9) A television or radio programme that has been broadcast before.
Example: is it a repeat? no, its a new series.     
(10) An order of goods or a prescription of medicine that is the same as one you had before.
(11) The sign that tells a performer to play a piece of music again, or the music that is played again.
(12) To achieve the same results, level of performance etc.
Example: It was the best-selling car last year and may well repeat that success this year.
(13) An event, situation etc that is very similar to one that has happened before.
Example: I dont think this year will see a repeat of last years earnings.

(1) If something repels you, it is so unpleasant that you do not want to be near it, or it makes you feel ill.
Example: The smell repelled him. 
(2) To make someone who is attacking you go away, by fighting them.
Example: The army was ready to repel an attack. 
(3) To keep something or someone away from you.
Example: A lotion that repels mosquitoes 
(4) If two things repel each other, they push each other away with an electrical force.
Example: Two positive charges repel each other.
(1) Sorry for something wrong that you have done.

(1) All the plays, pieces of music etc that a performer or group knows and can perform.
Example: The group include some techno in their repertoire. 
(2) The total number of things that someone or something is able to do.
Example: The behavioural repertoire of infants

(1) A type of theatre work in which actors perform different plays on different days, instead of doing the same play for a long time.
Example: A repertory company 
(2) A repertoire.

(1) Doing or saying the same thing many times.
Example: The job involved the constant repetition of the same movements. 
(2) Something that happens again, especially something bad.
Example: A repetition of the same problem

(1) To start doing something instead of another person, or start being used instead of another thing.
Example: Im replacing sue on the team. 
(2) To remove someone from their job or something from its place, and put a new person or thing there.
Example: Two of the tyres had to be replaced. 
(3) If you replace something that has been broken, stolen etc, you get a new one.
Example: Ill replace the vase i broke as soon as possible. 
(4) To put something back where it was before.
Example: He replaced the book on the shelf. 
(5) To start being used, doing a job etc instead of something or someone else.
Example: The tax replaces a levy of 13.5% on manufactured goods.
(6) To start using something instead of something else.
Example: Annual wage increases will be replaced with a bonus system.
(7) To remove someone from their job, position etc and give the job to a different person.
Example: They replaced the permanent staff with part-timers.
(8) To give someone a product instead of one that they bought which was damaged or not perfect.
Example: The shop offered to replace the television for me.

(1) To put new supplies into something, or to fill something again.
Example: More vaccines are needed to replenish our stocks. 
(2) To make something full again by adding new supplies to replace those that have been used.
Example: Manufacturers are scheduling overtime work to replenish low inventories.

(1) Full of something.
Example: Literature is replete with tales of power. 
(2) Very full of food or drink.

(1) An exact copy of something, especially a building, a gun, or a work of art.
Example: An exact replica of the taj mahal

(1) If you replicate someone’s work, a scientific study etc, you do it again, or try to get the same result again.
Example: There is a need for further research to replicate these findings. 
(2) If a virus or a molecule replicates, or if it replicates itself, it divides and produces exact copies of itself.
Example: The ability of dna to replicate itself

(1) A written or spoken description of a situation or event, giving people the information they need.
Example: Colleges have to provide a written report on the progress of each student during the year. 
(2) A piece of writing in a newspaper about something that is happening, or part of a news programme.
Example: According to recent news reports , two of the victims are americans. 
(3) An official document that carefully considers a particular subject.
Example: A recent report on child abuse 
(4) Information that something has happened, which may or may not be true.
Example: Police received reports of a bomb threat at the airport at 11:28 p.m.  11  28 
(5) A written statement by teachers about a child’s work at school, which is sent to his or her parents.
(6) Someone who works for a particular manager.
Example: Only gordons direct reports are attending the course. 
(7) The noise of an explosion or shot.
Example: A loud report 
(8) To give people information about recent events, especially in newspapers and on television and radio.
Example: This is gavin williams, reporting from the united nations in new york.   
(9) Used to say that a statement has been made about someone or something, but you do not know if it is true.
Example: The stolen necklace is reported to be worth $57,000.  5.7 
(10) To tell someone about what has been happening, or what you are doing as part of your job.
Example: Ive asked him to come back next week and report on his progress. 
(11) To officially give information to the public.
Example: Doctors have reported a 13% increase in the number of people with heart disease.  13% 
(12) To tell the police or someone in authority that an accident or crime has happened.
Example: Id like to report a theft. 
(13) To complain about someone to people in authority.
Example: Polish referee ryszard wojoik reported two leeds united players for violent conduct.   
(14) To go somewhere and officially state that you have arrived.
Example: All visitors must report to the site office. 
(15) To officially tell your employers that you cannot come to work because you are ill.
(16) To give someone information about something that they asked you to find out about.
Example: The committee has 60 days to report back to congress.  60 
(17) To be responsible to someone at work and be managed by them.
Example: He will report to greg carr, boston technologys chief executive.   
(18) A written or spoken description of a situation or event.
Example: A favorable first quarter earnings report
(19) A report presented each year by the directors of a company to the members and shareholders, containing financial information about the company’s trading activities and the documents the company must produce by law, which are the balance sheet, the profit and loss account and the auditor’s and directors' reports.
Example: The companys annual report revealed a rise of 3.8% in overall passenger income to 7.2 million.
(20) An official document produced by a group of people, examining a particular subject. people often use the name of the committee producing the report to talk about it.
Example: The cadbury report on the financial aspects of corporate governance
(21) A newspaper article or part of television or radio programme about a particular situation or event.
Example: According to a report in the financial times, several potential buyers are interested in the company.
(22) A manager’s reports are the people who work for him or her.
Example: Get feedback about your effectiveness from your boss, your peers, and your direct reports (= the people who are directly below you in your organization ) .
(23) If a company reports a profit, loss etc, it announces publicly how much profit etc it has made.
Example: The company reported second-quarter earnings of $25.1 million.
(24) To give people information about an event, situation etc.
Example: His remarks were first reported in yesterdays chicago tribune.
(25) To officially state you have arrived in an office, factory etc, usually by signing your name.
Example: All delivery vehicles please report to the site office.

(1) A state of calm or comfortable rest.
Example: His face looked less hard in repose. 
(2) If something reposes somewhere, it has been put there.
(3) If someone reposes somewhere, they rest there.
(4) To trust someone to help you.

(1) Reprehensible behaviour is very bad and deserves criticism.
Example: I find their behaviour morally reprehensible .

(1) To officially speak or take action for another person or group of people.
Example: Mr kobayashi was chosen to represent the company at the conference. 
(2) To speak officially for someone in a court of law.
Example: She decided to represent herself (= speak for herself without a lawyer ) during the trial. 
(3) To form or be something.
Example: European orders represented 30 percent of our sales last year.  30% 
(4) To have been elected to a parliament, council etc by the people in a particular area.
Example: He represents the congressional district of illinois. 
(5) To be a sign or mark that means something.
Example: Brown areas represent deserts on the map. 
(6) To be a symbol of something.
Example: He hated the school and everything it represented. 
(7) If you represent your country, school, town etc in a sport, you take part in a sports event for that country etc.
Example: Her greatest ambition was to represent her country at the olympics. 
(8) If a group, organization, area etc is represented at an event, people from it are at the event.
Example: All the local clubs were represented in the parade. 
(9) To describe someone or something in a particular way, especially in a way that is not true.
Example: The article represents the millionaire as a simple family man. 
(10) If a painting, statue, piece of music etc represents something or someone, it shows them.
Example: Paintings representing religious themes were common in medieval times. 
(11) To speak or go somewhere officially in order to state the views, opinions etc of another person or group of people.
Example: Workers hired during the strike are opposed to being represented by the union.
(12) If something represents a proportion of something else, it is equal to it.
Example: The sale represents only 1.6% of the companys average daily production.
(13) If part of a graph, chart etc represents something, it shows that information.
Example: The blue line represents the target income for the planning period.

(1) When you have someone to speak, vote, or make decisions for you.
Example: Minority groups need more effective parliamentary representation. 
(2) A painting, sign, description etc that shows something.
Example: The clock in the painting is a symbolic representation of the passage of time. 
(3) The act of representing someone or something.
Example: She received praise for her effective representation of garcia during the trial. 
(4) A formal complaint or statement.
Example: A group of students made representations to the college about the poor standard of the accommodation. 
(5) To describe or explain something in a way that you know is not true.
(6) When someone else speaks for you.
Example: There has been a decline in union representation in the auto industry.
(7) A formal complaint or statement.
Example: The drivers said they had not been given an opportunity to make representations before the ban was imposed.

(1) Someone who has been chosen to speak, vote, or make decisions for someone else.
Example: A union representative 
(3) A member of the house of representatives, the lower house of congress in the united states.
(4) Typical of a particular group or thing.
Example: The latest incident is representative of a wider trend. 
(5) Including examples of all the different types of something in a group.
Example: The pollsters asked a representative sample of new york residents for their opinions. 
(6) A representative system of government allows people to vote for other people to represent them in the government.
Example: A representative democracy 
(7) A person who sells a company’s products or services by speaking to customers on the phone or travelling to meet them.
Example: The work of a sales representative includes after-sales service.
(8) Someone chosen to speak or make decisions for another person or group of people.
Example: Make sure your employees representatives are involved.
(9) Like other members of the same group, and therefore showing what they are all like.
Example: Unfortunately, your sample is not statistically representative of the population.

(1) To stop yourself from doing something you want to do.
Example: Brenda repressed the urge to shout at him. 
(2) If someone represses upsetting feelings, memories etc, they do not allow themselves to express or think about them.
Example: He had long ago repressed the painful memories of his childhood. 
(3) To control a group of people by force.
Example: The police were widely criticized for their role in repressing the protest movement.

(1) A delay before something bad happens or continues to happen.
Example: Shoppers will get a temporary reprieve from the new sales tax. 
(2) An official order stopping the killing of a prisoner as a punishment.
Example: The us supreme court voted against granting smith a reprieve (= against giving him one ) . 
(3) To officially stop a prisoner from being killed as a punishment.
(4) To change a decision to close a factory, school etc or get rid of something.

(1) Criticism, blame, or disapproval.
Example: you dont need me,  she said quietly, without reproach.    
(2) A remark that expresses criticism, blame, or disapproval.
Example: He argued that the reproaches were unfair. 
(3) Impossible to criticize.
Example: His behaviour throughout this affair has been beyond reproach. 
(4) Something that should make a person, society etc feel bad or ashamed.
Example: These derelict houses are a reproach to the city. 
(5) To blame or criticize someone in a way that shows you are disappointed at what they have done.
Example: He publicly reproached his son for his behavior. 
(6) To feel guilty about something that you think you are responsible for.
Example: Youve got nothing to reproach yourself for  it was his own decision.
(1) Someone who behaves in an immoral way – often used humorously.

(1) If an animal or plant reproduces, or reproduces itself, it produces young plants or animals.
Example: The turtles return to the coast to reproduce. 
(2) To make a photograph or printed copy of something.
Example: Klimts artwork is reproduced in this exquisite book. 
(3) To make something happen in the same way as it happened before.
Example: British scientists have so far been unable to reproduce these results. 
(4) To make something that is just like something else.
Example: With a good set of speakers, you can reproduce the orchestras sound in your own home.

(1) The act or process of producing babies, young animals, or plants.
Example: Scientists studied the reproduction, diet, and health of the dolphins. 
(2) The act of producing a copy of a book, picture, piece of music etc.
Example: Unauthorized reproduction of this publication is strictly forbidden. 
(3) A copy of a work of art, piece of furniture etc.
Example: A reproduction of vincent van goghs sunflowers     
(4) The work of copying documents, books etc or preparing them for printing.
Example: Bulk reproduction is performed by high-speed photocopiers.

(1) Relating to the process of producing babies, young animals, or plants.
Example: The human reproductive system 
(2) Relating to the copying of books, pictures, music etc.

(1) To criticize someone for something that they have done.
Example: Employees were reproved for smoking in the buildings restrooms.

(1) A type of animal, such as a snake or lizard, whose body temperature changes according to the temperature around it, and that usually lays eggs to have babies.
(2) Someone who is unpleasant or cannot be trusted.

(1) To refuse to accept or continue with something.
Example: He repudiated all offers of friendship. 
(2) To state or show that something is not true or correct.
Example: The book repudiates the racist stereotypes about black women. 
(3) To state that a contract, agreement, sale etc is no longer effective.
Example: This would be a breach of a condition which would enable the hirer to repudiate the contract.

(1) Very unpleasant and offensive.
Example: I find his political ideas totally repugnant.

(1) If something or someone repulses you, you think that they are extremely unpleasant.
Example: The very thought of his cold clammy hands repulsed me. 
(2) To fight someone and successfully stop their attack on you.
Example: Government troops repulsed an attack by rebel forces. 
(3) To refuse an offer of friendship or help in a way that is rude.

(1) Respected for being honest or for doing good work.
Example: If you have a burglar alarm fitted, make sure it is done by a reputable company. 
(2) Respected for honesty and good work.
Example: Consumers should buy only from reputable dealers offering unconditional guarantees.

(1) The opinion that people have about someone or something because of what has happened in the past.
Example: Judge kelso has a reputation for being strict but fair. 
(2) The opinion people have of something or someone, based on what has happened in the past.
Example: The firm has a very good reputation .

(1) Reputation.
Example: A man of high repute

(1) According to what some people say, but not definitely.
Example: She is reputed to be extremely wealthy.

(1) A polite or formal demand for something.
Example: They have made an urgent request for international aid. 
(2) A piece of music that is played on the radio because someone has asked for it.

Example: To request more information, please call our toll-free number. 
(4) To officially or formally ask for something.
Example: Enclosed, please find the information you requested.
(5) An official or formal demand for something.
Example: The fund group received 150,000 requests for its prospectus.

(1) To need something.
Example: Campbells broken leg will probably require surgery.

Example: You are required by law to wear a seat belt.

Example: The ruling requiring companies to disclose the value of stock
(4) To need something.
Example: At first, cd-roms required a special disk drive that cost around $700.

(1) Something that someone needs or asks for.
Example: The refugees main requirements are food and shelter. 
(2) Something that must be done because of a law or rule.
Example: If you are installing a new bathroom, it has to meet the requirements of the building regulations. 
(3) Something, especially good examination results, that a college, employer etc says you must have in order to do something.
Example: English 4 is a requirement for english majors. 
(4) Something that an official organization says a company or person must have or do.
Example: There are deed restrictions, including a requirement that the buyer live in the property.
(5) Something that someone needs or wants.
Example: A product that meets customer requirements

(1) Needed for a particular purpose.
Example: He lacks the requisite qualifications. 
(2) Something that is needed for a particular purpose.
Example: He lacked the moral requisites for marriage. 
(3) Needed for a particular purpose.
Example: The financiers may be willing to step in and provide the requisite guarantees.

(1) If someone in authority, especially the army, requisitions a building, vehicle, or food, they officially demand to have it during an emergency such as a war.
Example: The building was requisitioned as a military hospital for the duration of the war. 
(2) An official written order for something.
Example: Government aircraft requisitions
(3) To officially ask for something in writing.
Example: One of its stakeholders has requisitioned an extraordinary general meeting.

(1) To officially end a law, or change a decision or agreement.
(2) To officially end a law, agreement, or decision made earlier.
Example: The company has the right to rescind the agreement.

(1) To save someone or something from a situation of danger or harm.
Example: Survivors of the crash were rescued by helicopter.
